div.head: Art's Trea≈øury, or a profitable and plea≈øing Invitation to the Lovers of Ingenuity, contained in many extraordinary Experiments, Rarieties, new, and curious Inventions, &c.
PART I.
CHAP. I. The Art and My≈øtery of dying Silks, Stuffs, cloth, feathers, &c. In the mo≈øt curious and delightful Colours, with the manner of ordering, making and preparing them, &c.
div.p:
SO plea≈øing to the Eyes of mankind, are the various colours that we daily or frequently behold, that they in a manner captivate and detain even the fancy it ≈øelf with Wonder and Delight. Wherefore, I have thought it highly convenient, among≈øt the many
≈øtupendious Secrets and Curio≈øities this Book contains, as well tending to profit, as plea≈øure, if duly practi≈øed, to place the Art of colouring, vulgarly called dying, in the beginning, as an Introduction to the re≈øt, it being much wanted, and frequently coveted by publick and private Per≈øons, to be known, and rightly managed. Wherefore for its better Improvement, take the following Rules and Directions.

div.head: To colour or dye Wool, or Woollen Cloth a curious red.
div.p: Take a con≈øiderable quantity of Alum, and di≈ø≈øolve it in Water, wherein bran has been boiled and ≈øtrained out, putting the Cloth, Wool, or Yarn, to ≈øteep in it, which being well ≈øteeped, put it into other clear water, heating it over a gentle fire, putting thereto greening-Weed, two pounds, to four gallons of water, ≈øtirring it about; but not ≈øuffering it to boil; add more, a handful of un≈ølaked Lime, and as much Wood-A≈øhes, ≈øtirring about the materials, adding yet a like quantity of Lime, A≈øhes, and a pound of the Powder of Log-Wood, or red-Wood, and the like of Braziel, and ≈øo in three or four hours time, a very fair colour to your ≈øatisfaction will be taken.

div.head: To dye Linen Thread, or Cloth red, &c.
div.p: Take a pound of Sam-fleure; and ≈øuffer it, for the ≈øpace of twenty four hours, to ≈øoak in two Gallons of water, heating over a gentle fire; then add, half a pound of the powder of Braziel, two Ounces of Vermilion, and an Ounce of Alum, di≈ø≈øolved in a pint of fair water.

div.head: To dye a clear, or plea≈øant light Red.
div.p: Take Wheat Bran, half a Peck, two Ounces of Alum, and boil them in four gallons of fair water, then through a fine hair fieve, ≈øtrain out the liquid part, then di≈ø≈øolve in it half a pound of Alum, and the like quantiy of white Tartar, and put in the Stuff, Cloth, &c. intended for colouring, adding three pound of Madder, and perfect the colour at a moderate heat without boiling.

div.head: To dye Silk a Sanguine Colour.
div.p:
Take a pound of Alum, and two pound of Greening weed, brui≈øe them well and pour upon them fair water, add then half a pound of Ground-Braziel, heat them over the Fire, and put the ≈øilk in ≈øome part of the liquid matter, ≈øuffering it to ≈øeeth therein; and ≈øo renew it with the remainder, till you find your Colour take, and having ≈øo done three times, rin≈øe it in Lee
of Oak-bark, or Wood a≈øhes, and afterward in Water.

div.head: To dye a fair Blue.
div.p: Take white Silk, Stuff or Cloth that is white, and ≈øoak it in water, then having wrung the water out, add two pound of Woold or Woad, a pound of Indico, and three ounces of Alum, and then gently heat and di≈ø≈øolve them in the water, and ≈øo dip your materials, till you perceive the Colour has taken.

div.head: To dye a purple Colour.
div.p: Take the Silk, Stuff or Cloth, that has already taken a blue, and dip it in Braziel and Alumwater, at moderate heats; and you will ≈øoon perceive your Colour an≈øwer your Expectation.

div.head: To dye Carnation.
div.p: Take a dry purper, and ≈øoak it a night in Man's Urine; then take your Cloth, that has been ≈øoaked in Alum-water, and dryed again, and put it therein, ≈øuffer the purper before hand to be twice ≈øeethed in fair water; then ≈øet another Ve≈ø≈øel by the Fire, and ≈øuffer the Cloth to take the dye therein.

div.head: To dye a deep red Carnation.
div.p: Take Linen and woollen white, Gall, and alum it well, and take the herb call'd by the Dutch Foli, which is to be found on the banks of Ditches, to the quantity of a pound well dryed; Indian Lake, four ounces, Spani≈øh red, two ounces; make of the≈øe and Alum-water a hot Liquor, and dip your materials therein, at gentle heats three or four times, and it will afford a curious Colour.

div.head: To dye ≈øilk Quoins a curious red.
div.p: Steep fir≈øt your Silk in Alum-water, giving it a gentle heat, adding thereto in the heating, Branwater; then take a pound and a half of greening weed, and ≈øo heat it up, and put the Silk therein, but let it not ≈øeeth, then take it out and rin≈øe it in Ley, and after that in water, adding ≈øome Powder of Log-wood; and ≈øo heating it up a ≈øecond time, the bu≈øine≈øs will be perfected.

div.head: To dye a fair yellow.
div.p:
Take the Stalks, Leaves and Seeds, &c. of Wood, the roots being cut off, and lay them in ≈øoak in Ley of wood A≈øhes, for the ≈øpace of three hours, after that ≈øeeth them, till you think they are ≈øufficiently ≈øodden; then put them into hot water and Urine, and heat them up indifferent
different well ≈øtraining the liquid part through a ≈øieve, adding to every two pounds of woad, two pounds of Verdigrea≈øe, with the Ley already ≈øod, ≈øtirring and well mixing it together in your Liquor, for the ≈øpace of three hours, and ≈øo dip into it very hot at three or four times what you intend to colour.

div.head: Another way to dye a curious Purple, viz.
div.p: In ca≈øe, it be ≈øilk you intend to dye, you mu≈øt to one pound of it take four ounces of Alum and a gallon of water, di≈ø≈øolving the Alum therein o'er a gentle Fire; putting then the Silk therein, and ≈øuffering it to lie, for the ≈øpace of four hours; then take of Indian Lake and Indico, each a quarter of a pound, add likewi≈øe a quart of Urine, and ≈øo heat them up into a dye, adding more about a handful of Cochinele.

div.head: A curious green water to make.
div.p: Take half an ounce of Verdigrea≈øe, brui≈øe it well, put thereto the yolk of an Egg, and a few blades of Saffron; then take of the Leaves of Spurge half a handful, brui≈øe them with a quarter of a pint of Vinegar, ≈øtraining the liquid part through a cloth, and mingle it with the materials before mentioned, ≈øo thin that it may take, either in dying or painting.

div.head: To make a black water to dye Silk Cloth, &c.
div.p: Take half a pound of Nut-galls, add to them a pottle of water, and an ounce of Lamb-black, with a handful of the ru≈øt or filings of Iron, heat them up, adding half a pound of coperas, ≈øeeth them to a half Con≈øumption, adding then a pint of Gum-water, and ≈øo ≈øet it by for your u≈øe, &c. and it will prove excellent good, the longer it is kept, it being the better.

div.head: To dye Linen or Silk a Ro≈øe red.
div.p: Take to every four yards and a half, a pound of Nut-galls, and ≈øeeth them in fair water unbru≈øed, for the ≈øpace of two hours, when pouring out the liquid part into another Ve≈ø≈øel or Fatt, put your Linen, &c. into it, and ≈øuffer it to ≈øoak for the ≈øpace of four hours; then wring it dry, and heat it again in Alum and fair water, adding half a pound of Braziel powder, and a pound of Greening-weed, and ≈øo by gentle heats make up your colour to the heighth.

div.head: To dye a fair green.
div.p:
Take Bran-water and Alum, a Gallon of the former, to a pound of the latter, and ≈øeeth them up, till the Alum is di≈ø≈øolved; then for about a quarter of an hour, let your Silk or Cloth lie therein; then take more Bran-water and a few
handfuls of woad, and put it therein, till it become a dark yellow; then add Verdigrea≈øe and Indico of each half a pound or more, or le≈øs of the one or the other, as you would have it lighter or darker.

div.head: To dye a good black.
div.p: Take two pounds of Galls, and half a pound of Coperas, ≈øeeth them in water over a gentle Fire, putting your Silk, Stuff or Cloth therein, and ≈øtirring it about; then hang it to dry, and prepare your dye in this manner, viz. Take a large Fatt, and put therein three or four handfuls of Rye Meal, and half ≈øo much of ≈øwarf of the Grind-≈øtone or Smiths water, with two handfulls of elder bark, and the like quantity of the ru≈øt of Iron, and having ≈øuffered it to ≈øtand for the ≈øpace of three days, heat it up and put your materials therein, &c.

div.head: To make a thick water to work on yellow Silk the be≈øt way.
div.p: Take two quarts of the be≈øt Varni≈øh, add to it an ounce of the Flower of Sulphur, half an ounce of Camphire; then ≈øeeth it a while, and ≈øuffer it to cool, ≈øtraining it through a Cloth, to take away the gro≈ø≈øer part; and when you u≈øe it, let it be mixed with a ≈ømall quantity of Gum-Arabick water.

div.head: To make a curious red Water.
div.p: Take two quarts of fair water, four ounces of Gum-Arabick, a pound of faucet Woad, ≈øeeth them together, till half be con≈øumed; and then taking it off, put into the remainder half an ounce of Spani≈øh green, and about thirty grains of Cochinele, and ≈øo u≈øe it as you ≈øee convenient.

div.head: To make a curious blue Water for Silks, Stuffs, or Woollen.
div.p: Take three parts of Soap boilers A≈øhes, and one part of unquenched Lime, make of them a Ley, and ≈øuffer it well to ≈øettle, then add to the thinner part taken off, a pound of Boloemen, ≈øtirring them well together over a gentle fire, adding a pound of Woad, and half a pound of Indico, dipping what you intend to colour therein when it is very hot.

div.head: To work on yellow Silk, white, grey, or Azure Colour.
div.p: Take a pottle of fair water, and a fourth part of Gum-Arabick, and half a pottle of faucet Woad, an ounce of Ar≈øhick, and the like quantity of Turmerick ground ≈ømall, and ≈øeeth them over a gentle Fire, putting a ≈ømall quantity of Grains therein, and ≈øo apply it to your u≈øe, as you ≈øee convenient.

div.head: To make a red Water for white Silk or Wool, green, yellow, Violet or Azure.
div.p: Take two quarts of running water, and an ounce of Braziel, heat them up till half be conlumed, then take it off the Fire, and put in an ounce of Grains, and a quarter of an ounce of Gum Arabick, with a quarter of a pound of Alum Powder, and ≈øuffering it to ≈øtand all night, in the Morning you may u≈øe it.

div.head: To make grey Florey.
div.p: Take Florey, and ≈øoak it twenty four hours, at the end of which, wring it through a Cloth, then take the A≈øhes of the Vine, and make a Ley with them, and ≈øpread the Florey for the ≈øpace of two hours upon a Table, and having put the Ley into three Ve≈ø≈øels, take the Florey, and put it into one of the ≈øaid Ve≈ø≈øels, and ≈øo ≈øhift it to the re≈øt, putting before you dip your Linen, &c. Vinegar to it, and your Colour will be good.

div.head: To dye Linen with Crampmede.
div.p:
U≈øe in this a pound of Crampmede, to three Ells of Linen, and put it to a gallon and a half of water, or ≈øo proportionable to the quantity, and warm it over the Fire, till it appears ready to ≈øeeth; then add to it two ounces of Galls, and ≈øo put your Linen into it, and as often as you
take it out, which mu≈øt be frequent, wring it, when having a pot of fair water ready heated with Alum di≈ø≈øolved in it, put the Linen well wrung into it; and ≈øo rub it over at the taking out, and dry it; but if you would have it the darker Colour; then is it requi≈øite to have a Ley made with Lime-Stones, or un≈ølaked Chalk, &c.

div.head: To dye Velvet, or other things requiring it, the mo≈øt curious of Blacks.
div.p: Take of Galls two pound, Coperas half a pound, Smiths water a G ‚Ä¢ llon, the powder of burnt Ivory an ounce, and of Oak bark, and Shooe-makers black ground to powder, the like quantity, and two gallons of fair water, mix them well together, and ≈øuffer them to ≈øtand in the Sun or ≈øome other warm place for the ≈øpace of thirty days, with often ≈øtirring about, then put your materials therein, and as often as you di ‚Ä¢ , hang them to dry, and your expectation will be an≈øwered.

div.p: Take half a peck of Wheat Bran, and two gallons of fair water, ≈øet them on the Fire, giving them a gentle heat, which being done, put half a pound of Alum powder into it, and ≈øuffer it to ≈øtand a week or more, with ≈øometimes ≈øtirring it about before you u≈øe it.

div.p: Take four pound of Wooll or yarn, two pound of Woad, putting the Woad into a Kettle to two gallons of water; then throw in two handfuls of Wood-A≈øhes, and when it ≈øeetheth, put your Wool or Yarn into it, and let it remain there about half an hour, at what time take it out and wring it and put it in again, and let it ≈øeeth as long as before; and then if it be before a brown blue, it will be a dark green, or if it was white, it will be a yellowi≈øh colour. And thus much at pre≈øent, in relation to Colours for dying Silks, cloth, &c.

div.head: CHAP. II. The mo≈øt curious Art and Method of colouring Skins, or any peices or parcels of Leather or Bri≈øtles; as al≈øo of gilding Leather with Gold, laying with Silver or Lacquering, &c.

div.p:
TAke the Leaves of Night-≈øhade, brui≈øe them in a Mortar, ≈øtrain out the juice, and di≈ø≈øolve in a pint two ounces of Alum, add half
an ounce of Verdigrea≈øe, and heat them gently over the Fire, and then ≈øuffering it to ≈øtand for twenty four hours, ≈øtrike over the Skin with it warm, and ≈øuffering it to dry, do it again till it has taken the Colour, which will be very lively.

div.head: To colour black Leather after the Order in Germany, &c.
div.p: Take of the Bark of Elder two pounds, of the filings or ru≈øt of Iron the like quantity, put to them two Gallons of Rain-water; and ≈øtop them up clo≈øe in a Cask or other Ve≈ø≈øel, and ≈øo ≈øuffer them to ≈øtand for the ≈øpace of two Months; then put to the liquid part a pound of Nut-galls beaten to Powder, and a quarter of a pound of Coperas, heating them over the Fire, and ≈øuffering them to ≈øtand twenty four hours after, and ≈øo u≈øe them with a bru≈øh, till the Skin has taken an excellent black.

div.p:

dry them in the Sun or in ≈øome warm hou≈øe, and they will be u≈øeful on ≈øundry occa≈øions, without any further trouble.

div.head: To make white Leather blue.
div.p: Take the Berries of Elder a quart, ≈øtrain out the juice and boil it with an ounce of the powder of Alum, and half an ounce of Indico, or ≈ømalt blue, and bru≈øh over the Leather with a fine bru≈øh dipped therein three or four times, ≈øuffering it to dry between whiles, and the bu≈øine≈øs will be effected.

div.p: Having rubbed your Leather well with Alumwater or alumed it, take ≈øtale Urine, ≈øeeth it and ≈øcum it till half be wa≈øted; put then to it an ounce of the fine≈øt Lake with the like quantity of Braziel in Powder, an ounce of Alum, and half an ounce of Sal-armoniac, mix them well and keep them ≈øtirring over a gentle Fire about two hours, and ≈øo u≈øe the liquid part, and your expectation will be an≈øwered.

div.p:

div.p: Take that which the Dutch call Pomplemelch, warm it, and rub the Leather therewith, then take of Venis tot Appelen, and having beaten it ≈ømall, put a con≈øiderable quantity of fair water to it, and let it ≈øoften over a gentle Fire; then pre≈øs out the water, and ≈øo in the liquid part rub or wa≈øh the Skin, doing it ≈øo often; and after that, take Shooe makers black the ≈øine≈øt, and rub over the Skin with it, having in the wetting added to it a little Vitriol or Coperas, and ≈øuffering it to dry, take Goo≈øe or Hogs-grea≈øe in a Woollen Cloth, and rub the Skin over for a good ≈øpace, where there is a good Fire to ≈øupple it in; and then rub it over with your hands, till it di≈øappear, or in≈øtead of Grea≈øe, Line-≈øeed, or train Oil may be u≈øed, and ≈øo in ca≈øe of any other Colour, according as the Colours are de≈øigned.

div.p:

div.p: Take an ounce of Indico, as much of Bi≈ø≈øe, as much Alum as a Hazle-nut, put them into Gum water, and dip the materials into it hot, hang them up to dry, and clap them well, that they may open. And ≈øo changing the Colours, you may in this manner dye the afore≈øaid materials of any Colour, as for black u≈øe Log-wood, and Galls for Purple, Lake and Indico; for Carnation. Vermilion and Smalt, for yellow, yellow Berries and Saffion with a little Tartar mingled or di≈ø≈øolved in your Gum-water.

div.p:
Take the materials and ≈øoften them in water wherein Tartar has been di≈ø≈øolved; then take Vermilion and Braziel, temper them well in water, boil them up in a Liquor, and put your Horn, Ivory, or Bone into it, and ≈øuffer either
of them to be there, it being hot, for a convenient time, and taking them in≈øtantly, out ca≈øt them into cold Alum-water; and if they have not taken the Tincture at fir≈øt, u≈øe them in the like manner a ≈øecond time; and ≈øo proportioning the Colours, you may in this manner proceed to make them take what Colour you plea≈øe.

div.p: Take four ounces of Gum-Arabick, di≈ø≈øolve it in two quarts of fair water; then provide ≈øeveral Colours mixed with water in pots or ≈øhells, and with peculiar pencils to every Colour, ≈øprinkle them by way of inter-mixture upon the Gum-water, which mu≈øt be in a Trough, or ≈øome broad Ve≈ø≈øel; then with a ≈øtick curl them and draw them out in ≈øtreaks, to as much variety as may be; which done, hold your Book or Books clo≈øe together, and only dip the Edges in on the top of the water, and Colours, very lightly; which done, take them off, and the plain Impre≈ø≈øion of the Colours in mixture will be upon the Leaves, doing as well the ends as the Front of the Book in like manner: and in this ca≈øe, you may do paper by dipping it on the flat, as al≈øo Linen Cloth, &c.

div.p:

two hours; then having prepared your Colours very hot, boil the Hair therein, and any Colour, black excepted, will take, but that will only take a dark red or dark blue, &c. And after this manner with Colours cold, or but like-warm, you may dye the feathers upon the backs of Poultry, wild fowl, hair on Dogs, Hor≈øes, or the like, in as much varieties as your Fancy can ≈øugge≈øt.

div.p: Wet your Skins or Fells in Alum water, in which has been di≈ø≈øolved a like quantity of Salt with half as much Lime, when being again ≈øtretched and dryed, take the la≈øt of Brewers drink a quart, put into it an ounce of Braziel powder, a quarter of an ounce of Vermilion, and an ounce of Alum-powder, thicken them over a gentle Fire, by continual ≈øtirring, and ≈øo with a bru≈øh or Cloth, rub over the Skins at an evenne≈øs, not laying it thicker on one place than another, and ≈øo do three times ≈øucce≈ø≈øively, ≈øuffering them only to dry the mean while, and your expectation will be an≈øwered.

div.p:

div.p: Take Smalt two ounces, red wine a quarter of a pint, Alum two ounces, Vinegar half a Pint, and white ≈øtarch half an ounce, put them over a gentle Fire, not ≈øuffering them to become over thick; and then ≈øoaking the Skins with Alum-water, and ≈øuffering them to dry as u≈øually, add to this colouring half a pint of Gumwater tolerably thick, and lay it on, glazing it over when dry with a poli≈øher.

div.p:

div.head: CHAP. III. How to recover faded Colours in Cloth or Silk, to take Spots, Stains, Pitch, Tar, Ro≈øin, Grea≈øe, Wax, Oil, &c. out of Silks, Stuffs, Woollen or Linen, to pre≈øerve them from Damage of Worms, Moths, &c. and other matters, &c.

div.p: TAke of unquenched Lime two ounces, of the A≈øhes of the Bark of Oak, the like quantity, and put them into a quart of fair water, mixing them well, and ≈øuffering a ≈øettlement for the ≈øpace of an hour, drawing off the clear part, and therewith wa≈øh or carry over with a hard bru≈øh the Cloth, and by twice or thrice carrying it over, it will look fair and bright.

div.p: Take Wood Sorrel and di≈øtil it in an Alimbeck with Fumitory, and wa≈øh the damaged place therewith, and it will in frequently ≈øo doing re≈øtore it.

div.p: Heat rain-water, and when it is very hot, put into it ca≈øteel Soap, di≈ø≈øolve it well; then ≈øuffer it to be almo≈øt cold, after which, ≈øprinkle in a ≈ømall quantity of fulling Earth, and ≈øo ≈øcowre out your Silks; then ≈øuffer them not to lie on heaps, but ≈øpread them, and clap them between clean dry Cloaths, and they will be fre≈øh and fair.

div.head: CHAP. VI. To draw the Face in divers Po≈øtures and Proportions, the mo≈øt exact Rules, and what of variety is to be con≈øidered therein.
For drawing the face, general Rules, &c.
div.p:
IN this ca≈øe curiou≈øly ob≈øerve the face in its motion, whether upward, forward, downward, or ≈øide-ways, touching lightly the features, where the Eyes, No≈øe, Mouth, and Chin ought to ≈øtand; then more perfectly go over them, for the Circles, Squares and Triangles, that are u≈øed in this matter, may ≈øerve well enough, to guide your Judgment where to place them. And in this ca≈øe, ob≈øerve diligently the principal Mu≈øcles of a Face, appearing mo≈øt in aged Men or Women. And there is u≈øual a threefold proportion
ob≈øerved in a Face, as fir≈øt from the top of the Fore-head to the Eye brows. Secondly, from the Brows to the bottom of the No≈øe, and Thirdly, from thence to the bottom of the Chin, but in ≈øome the Fore-head is lower, and in others the No≈øe longer.

The di≈øtances between the Eyes con≈øi≈øt in a full Face of the length of one Eye, but in a three quarter, or ≈øide-face, that di≈øtance is le≈ø≈øened an≈øwerable to the proportion. As for the No≈øtril, it ought to be exactly placed again≈øt the corner of the Eye. And in a fat face, you will perceive the cheeks to ≈øwell, when on the contrary, in a lean face, the Jaw-bones ≈øtick out, and the cheeks fall in.

You may di≈øcern a ≈ømiling countenance, by perceiving the corners of the Mouth to turn up a little, and a frowning or ≈øowre countenance, by the Fore-heads bending and ≈øomewhat wrinkling on the top of the No≈øe.

To draw a fore-right Face, make the form of a perfect Oval, divided into three equal parts, by two Lines. In the fir≈øt part, place the Eyes: In the ≈øecond, the No≈øtrils: And in the third, the Mouth, ob≈øerving to keep the Eyes di≈øtant from each other, the length of one Eye, and that their inward corners be perfectly over the out ≈øide of the No≈øtrils.
To draw an upright head, it mu≈øt be made equal with three Lines, every way, either upwards, downwards, higher or lower, and that mu≈øt, as the former, be divided into three equal parts.

To draw the Inclining, or fore-≈øhortened face, ob≈øerve how the Lines concord or agree together, and with ea≈øe, you may draw, in their proper places, the No≈øe, Mouth, and other parts, with a little Practice, and in the≈øe forms it is requi≈øite that you are very perfect as being rules of frequent u≈øe; for of the many parts of Man's Body, the face is mo≈øt difficult; but having got the true proportion, with your mea≈øures, you will be capable, let the face turn which way it will, to form it; and further note, that what≈øoever proportion the Face you are to imitate bears, your out ≈øtroaks mu≈øt be formed accordingly.

As for the No≈øe, it requires to its due proportion much care and diligence, as being the mo≈øt eminent part of the Face; in which, e≈øpecially, ob≈øerve the hollowne≈øs, roundne≈øs, and indenting of the No≈øtrils, &c.

The next thing, e≈øpecially where the body is to be covered, is to be con≈øidered of the Hands, in their ≈øeveral po≈øtures and po≈øitions, as well by mea≈øure, as without, as al≈øo Hands, and Arms of who≈øe po≈øtures, as well as the former, it would not be unnece≈ø≈øary for the Learner, to get draughts for his better imitation, which may be had at mo≈øt Picture Shops, for a ≈ømall matter ready done.

When you have practi≈øed, and are a little expert in drawing the Hands and Arms, &c. proceed to the drawing of Feet in their ≈øeveral Po≈øtures, as well without, as with mea≈øure;
which having attained ≈øeparate, exerci≈øe your skill in drawing Legs and Feet conjunct or joined together, that ≈øo under≈øtanding the frame and particulars of the whole body, you may be the better under≈øtanding in drawing the Figures in their due proportion and right Po≈øtures, in doing which there is no ≈ømall difficulty. And in this manner, having proceeded to form the Members, draw the other parts of the body, as the Shoulders, Back, Brea≈øt, Belly, Secrets, Thighs, and the like, and la≈øtly take care in due proportion to join them, that they may appear firm and compleat.

Coming to practi≈øe upon an entire body the be≈øt way is to begin with tho≈øe of Children; and my rea≈øon is, becau≈øe they are generally fat and plump, and rounder than the Bodies of Men and Women, and con≈øequently require ≈øo much curio≈øity in the ob≈øervation of Mu≈øcles and other Features, which render the drawing le≈øs difficult.

As for your further Direction in drawing, ob≈øerve ever to begin at the Head, and ≈øo proceed by degrees, running the whole lightly over at the fir≈øt, and encrea≈øing more fully, as you ≈øee occa≈øion, ever being careful to take notice, that your parallel Joints, Mu≈øcles, Sinews, &c. be rightly proportioned, and exactly oppo≈øite; al≈øo that the motions of the Body be an≈øwerable to each other, and that the Parts and Limbs have a due Symmetry, not being faulty in the indecency of having one great Arm or Leg, and another
≈ømall one, nor a great Finger upon a ≈ømall Hand, neither further than the proportion requires, ≈øuffer one Limb, or Member to be longer than another; and although it ≈øo happen, which it frequently does, that at fir≈øt you commit Errors of this nature, yet be not di≈øcouraged, for frequent practice will redre≈øs them.
Having thus far proceeded with Succe≈øs, and being indi≈øterent perfect herein, you mu≈øt con≈øider what it is to ≈øhadow; and in this ca≈øe, ob≈øerve the following Rules, viz.

The out Lines of the draught of any Picture, give the ≈øymmetry or proportion, which ought to be ≈øufficient to a good Judgment, but the Lines and Shadows produce to the le≈øs curious, the lively likene≈øs in ≈øhadowing; therefore of any Picture, you mu≈øt take notice to ca≈øt your ≈øhadow always one way, viz. on which ≈øide ≈øoever you begin to ≈øhadow your Figure, whether on the right or left Hand, as in the Figure of a Man, if you fir≈øt proceed to ≈øhadow his left Cheek, the left ≈øide of his Neck, Body, and all other parts mu≈øt be ≈øhadowed, unle≈øs the light ≈øide of the Figure be dark, by rea≈øon of ≈øome other Body ≈øtanding between the Light and it, as ≈øuppo≈øe three men were ≈øtanding together; then mu≈øt the Body, or Figure in the middle be darkened by the foremo≈øt, unle≈øs the light by facing it come between them.

Further, note, that all ≈øhadows mu≈øt con≈øequently grow fainter, as they are further removed from the opacous Body from whence they
proceed. But in ca≈øe of Storms, where Clouds, or Waves, by contending Winds are driven one again≈øt another, contrary ≈øhadows are allowed, as ≈øtriving for Superiority, and ≈øo you mu≈øt be ≈øure to ≈øupply the greate≈øt fir≈øt, and according to your Judgment, ≈øupply from them the le≈ø≈øer.
All circular Bodies mu≈øt have a circular ≈øhadow, as they have a circular form, and as the object of Light which cau≈øeth the ≈øhadow is circular.

And now for your further Information of this kind, ob≈øerve that a Man ≈øtanding from the top of the head, to the bottom of the feet, is in due proportion eight times the length of the Head. The Arm when it hangeth ≈øtraight down, reacheth within a ≈øpan of the Knee; the Hand mu≈øt be the length of the Face, and ≈øpread broad, mu≈øt cover it, and no more; and further note, that in drawing a Figure ≈øtanding, you mu≈øt in the fir≈øt place draw that Leg, which the Body ≈øtands firm upon, or el≈øe your Figure will undecently decline one way more than another, as if it were falling. The Arms of a Man extended are his full length; and ≈øo of a Woman in the various particulars. Thus having directed you in the drawing and proportioning naked Figures, I now proceed to give directions about Garments, &c.

As in naked Figures, it is ob≈øerved you draw the out-Lines fir≈øt; ≈øo you mu≈øt do in Drapery or Cloathing, leaving ≈øpace within for your greater or le≈ø≈øer folds; then fir≈øt draw the greater folds, and break them into le≈ø≈øer
contained within them, and the clo≈øer the Garment ≈øits to the Body, the narrower and ≈ømaller mu≈øt be the folds, and in ≈øhadowing, the innermo≈øt mu≈øt be the harder, and the outermo≈øt ≈øofter.

Continue always throughout your Garment the great folds, but as for the le≈ø≈øer, break them off, as you ≈øee convenient, and the finer your drapery is, the fuller, and ≈øharper mu≈øt your folds be, and the ≈øhadow the ≈øtronger, yet more plea≈øant to the Eye, ever taking notice, that that part of any Garment that ≈øits clo≈øe, as the body Coat of a Man, the Brea≈øts of a Woman, and the like, mu≈øt not at all be folded, but rather with a ≈øweet ≈øhadow repre≈øent that part of the Body, that the Garment appears to cover, as Woman's Brea≈øts, with a ≈øweet found ≈øhadow, &c. And thus much for the body of Man in drawing.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Land-skips, what they are, and what is required in the drawing, and curious proportioning them plea≈øant to the Eye of Fancy, &c.
div.p:
A Landskip is that which giveth a plea≈øant pro≈øpect of Trees, Hills, Rivers, Cattle, and other Rural delights, with Towns, Cities,
Ca≈øtles, Promontories, Rocks, Ships, Boats, Barges, and whatever the fancy of that kind can form. To expre≈øs which, and make all truly appear naturally, as they ought, according to the true proportion and di≈øtance, ob≈øerve in every Landskip, to make a very fair Horizon appear, the Sky either clear, or over-ca≈øt with Clouds, expre≈ø≈øing the ri≈øing or ≈øetting of the Sun, to i≈ø≈øue as it were from or over ≈øome Hill, Mountain or Rock; but in a fair Landskip, beware you expre≈øs not the Moon or Stars, which are only to be ≈øeen in a Night-piece; and in ca≈øe, ≈øuch a piece be required, you may draw an A≈øtronomer with his Quadrate, taking the height of the Moon, another with his Cro≈øs≈øtaff, taking the di≈øtance of certain Stars, ≈øome ≈øtanding with a dark Lanthorn far from them, to give them knowledge of their degrees, an Owl flying in the Air, Men catching of Partridges with low Bells, a Woolf worrying of Sheep and the like, being natural to ≈øuch pieces.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. The curious and much e≈øteemed Science of Painting or Limning in Water Colours, and how exactly to proceed therein, either on Parchment, Gla≈øs or Copper, with the mixture, and di≈øtinction of the ≈øundry Colours, and other rare Curio≈øities.
div.p: HAving gone over that which we may properly term limning, or as many will have it drawing, I now come to that part, vulgarly known by the Appellation of Limning, viz. laying in water Colours the mo≈øt curious of all, and much practi≈øed by Per≈øons of the be≈øt Quality.

To fit your ≈øelf, and prepare for the practice of this, you mu≈øt have Gums of all ≈øorts to make your waters as occa≈øion requires; al≈øo a Marble flat ≈øtone, a Muller, Colours of various forts, liquid Gold and Silver, Size to lay Gold,
&c. Parchment, of the fine≈øt pencils of ≈øundry ≈øorts, pots and Shells to put your Colours in.

To make your Gum-water take Gum-arabick, white, clear, or tran≈øparent, for that which is yellow, or of an Amber-Colour is in≈øignificant; tie up a quantity in a rag, and hang it in fair water, till it be di≈ø≈øolved; then the water being ≈øtiff enough for your purpo≈øe, mix your Colours with it, always having two ≈øorts to make a weaker or ≈øtronger, as the matter requires.

Gum-lake is a compound Gum, made of whites of Eggs, finely beat, Honey, Gum, of Ivy, ≈øtrong wort, &c. which being well mingled and beat together, they will run like Oil, and in the end harden, and this you may buy ready made, as the former, ob≈øerving only, that it be clear and tran≈øparent.

As for the Colours, there are ≈øimply ≈øix, viz. white, black, red, yellow, green, and blue, to which ≈øome add browns, but they are generally compounded, and of either of the≈øe, there are ≈øeveral ≈øorts, as the≈øe, viz. Blacks the be≈øt, are burnt Ivory, Cherry-≈øtones, Lamp-black. The whites are Ceru≈øs and white Lead. The reds are red Lead and Lake. The Blews are Indico, Ultramarine, Bi≈øe-≈ømalt. The Greens are bi≈øe, Sap-green, Pink, Cedar-green. The yellows are Engli≈øh Oker and Ma≈øticore. The Browns are Umber, Collens-earth, Spani≈øh- brown.

The≈øe (though there are others) are the principal Colours in limning; and therefore, I
chu≈øe to ≈øpeak of the≈øe only in this place, the others omitted, being fit only to colour Pictures or wa≈øh Maps, &c. and of the≈øe
The Colours to be wa≈øhed are Bi≈øe-≈ømak, Cedar, Ultramarine, Ma≈øticote, and red Lead. The Sap-green is only to be ≈øteeped, and the re≈øt I have meationed are to be wa≈øhed and ground.

To wa≈øh Colours, you mu≈øt put a quantity of the Colour intended into a clean earthen di≈øh, and pour water thereto very clear, ≈øtirring the Colour and water together, ≈øuffering it to ≈øtand a while, and perceiving the grea≈øe or ≈øcum to ri≈øe, take it off, and pour out that water, putting other water to the Colour, &c. and ≈øo do, till the water become clear, and the Colour at the bottom remain fine; then pour away the water gently, and you will find the Colour ≈øticking about the ≈øides and edges of the di≈øh, as al≈øo at the bottom, and if it ≈øo happen, that you can get an ounce of pure Colour out of a pound (tho the re≈øt is ≈øerviceable for many u≈øes) it is ≈øufficient.
In ≈øteeping Sap-Green, you mu≈øt put it only into fair water, adding a fourth part of Alumpowder to rai≈øe the Colour, and at the end of twenty four hours it will be a curious green.

As for the Colours that are to be wa≈øhed and ground, take a ≈ømall quantity of either; and put it into a clean ≈øhell, adding a drop or two of Gum-water, and work it about the ≈øides of the ≈øhell with your finger, ≈øuffering it there to ≈øtick,
till it is dry; then draw over it your Finger, and if any come off; then you mu≈øt add more Gumwater, but being dry, if it glitter or ≈øhine, it is a token there is too much Gum in it, which you mu≈øt remedy, by tempering it up with fair water only.

There are ≈øome Colours, as Umber and Lake, which parch and crack when they are dry, and therefore to bind them, you mu≈øt temper them with fine Sugar-Candy di≈ø≈øolved in fair water, and ≈øo you mu≈øt do by other hard Colours ≈øubject to this defect.

To burn the Colour thereto appropriated, put them into a crucible, cover it with a Lid of Clay, and ≈øet it on a hot fire, and ≈øuffer it to be red hot, and when the Colour is cold, you may wa≈øh or grind it, as the Nature requires, but do neither before they be throughly burnt.

To grind the Colours, I have directed ≈øo to be u≈øed, take a quantity of any of them clean≈øed from dirt and filth, and laying it upon your ≈øtone, brui≈øe it a little with your Muller; and then with fair water grind it, till the Colour be very fine, then have in readine≈øs a large chalk ≈øtone with troughs, or furrows in it, and pour your Colour into it, and there ≈øuffer it to remain till it be well dry, at what time take it out, and re≈øerve it in Papers, or Boxes for your u≈øe‚Äî
Of the≈øe ≈øix ≈øimple Colours, adding the brown, many may be compounded for faces of all Complexions, Garments, Land-skips, Building, Rivers, Birds, Fi≈øh, Bea≈øts, &c. As thus,
To make Violet Colour take Indico, white and Lake, and at plea≈øure, you may, as you take more or le≈øs of a Colour make it lighter, or darker at Plea≈øure.
Lead Colour, you may make of Indico, and white mixed and tempered together.
Make Flame Colour, or Colour for flaming Fire of red Lead and Ma≈øticote heightened with white.
To make a ≈øcarlet Colour, take red Lead, Lake, and a ≈ømall quantity of Vermilion: For note, that the latter is not good in limning.
To make light green, take Pink, and Smalt with white, to make it lighter, as occa≈øion requires.
To make a purple Colour, take Indico, Spani≈øh brown, and white well tempered and ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ightned
To make a Bay Colour, take only Spani≈øh brown and white.
To make a Murrrey Colour, take Lake and white.

Many other Colours are made by mixture, too tedious here to be recited; wherefore, I leave them to the di≈øcretion of the Practitioner, to mix them ≈øuitable to his work or fancy, and proceed to the practical part of this curious Art, &c.

div.head: CHAP. IX. In≈øtructions for the preparing your Tablets, and laying on your Colours in their graceful Shadows and proportion, and what is to be ob≈øerved, as to the Lines in the Face, Complexion, and Procedure in drawing curious, and many other matters.
div.p: WHen you have prepared your Colours, prepare likewi≈øe good Pencils, to know them, draw them wet through your Mouth, and if they come to a hair, or ≈øharp point, they are good, but if they after that ≈øtand rough, or hairs ≈øtare, or ≈øtart out at the ≈øide, they are nought, and to be rejected.

The next thing is to prepare your Table; and in this ca≈øe, get a fine Pa≈øte-board ≈øleeked as ≈ømooth as a Card; then fine Parchment or Vellum, and ≈øtarch it upon the board, as ≈ømooth and even, that no wrinkle, or ri≈øing may appear; to perfect which, you mu≈øt lay the Parchment ≈øide on your Stone rubbed very clean, and poli≈øh the contrary ≈øide, and ≈øo let it dry in the ≈øhade.

Having thus prepared a Table, as big as you intend your Picture, chu≈øe a Light fair and large, free from ≈øhadow, being if po≈ø≈øible a Sky-light on the top of a hou≈øe, yet ≈øuch a one, as the Sunbeams do not penetrate, or glance upon, ob≈øerving
to begin and end your work by one and the ≈øame light, keeping the room clean, that no du≈øt may fly about to prejudice your work.

The next thing to be con≈øidered is your manner of ≈øitting; and in this ca≈øe, let your Desk be ≈øo placed, that when you ≈øit before it, your left Arm may be placed toward your light, and your right Arm from it, that your light may ≈ølaunt upon your work. And if you are to draw the Picture of any live Per≈øon, the po≈øture being agreed upon, ≈øuffer him or her to ≈øit above two yards di≈øtant from you, and as level with you as may be, marking well, that when≈øoever the Party moves, though never ≈øo little, for never ≈øo little motion of the Body or Face, if not recalled, may occa≈øion in a ≈øhort time many Errors, and when you undertake this, the following Materials are requi≈øite to be near you, viz.

Two ≈ømall di≈øhes or ≈øawcers with clean water, the one to wa≈øh your Pencils in when foul, and the other to tamper your Colours withal; a fine large Pencil to clean≈øe your work, called a Fitch-pencil; a ≈øharp Pen-knife to take off hairs, coming from your Pencil or Spots, that may fall upon your Card; a Paper having holes cut therein, to lay upon your Card, to cover it from du≈øt, and to re≈øt your Hand upon.

If your Carnation, or fle≈øh Colour be tempered up, it mu≈øt be ≈øomewhat lighter, than the Complexion of the Party you are to draw. If it be a fair Complexion, you mu≈øt have white Lead, and red Lead well tampered. If the
Complexion be ≈øwarthy or brown, add to your white and red Lead, Ma≈øticote, or Engli≈øh Oker, or both, if occa≈øion require it; but let the Complexion be what it will, be ≈øure to tamper your Fle≈øh Colour lighter than the Party to be drawn; for if it be too ≈øad, there is no remedy; and ob≈øerve to place your Shadows di≈øtinct from each other in a large ≈øhell: And note, that in all your Shadows, you mu≈øt u≈øe ≈øome white, wherefore in the fir≈øt place, lay a con≈øiderable quantity of white by it ≈øelf, over and above what the ≈øhadows are at fir≈øt tempered withal. In the ≈øecond place, for red u≈øual to the cheeks, and Lips, tamper Lake, and red Lead. In the third place, for your blue ≈øhadows, as Veins, or under the Eyes, take Indico and white. In the fourth place, for your fainti≈øh green ≈øhadow, take Engli≈øh Oker, White, and Indico, or ≈øometimes Ma≈øticote. In the fifth place, for a deep ≈øhadow, take white, and Engli≈øh Oker, and Umber. Sixthly, for Dark ≈øhadows, in the Faces of Men, take Lake and Pink, for they make an excellent fle≈øhy ≈øhadow. And the≈øe being the chief ≈øhadows, I leave what may further occurr of this kind to your di≈øcretion.

Having all things in readine≈øs, the next thing you proceed to, is to draw the face, in doing which; take the following method, viz. lay the ground, with the Colour an≈øwerable to the Complexion of the Party; and then begin the draught, the Party ≈øitting. Now to fini≈øh a Face three Operations of ≈øitting are required. At
the fir≈øt ≈øitting, you mu≈øt only lay the dead Colour At the ≈øecond, go over the Face more curiou≈øly, nearly ob≈øerving what≈øoever may conduce to the Grace, or Deformity of the Per≈øon to be drawn, con≈øidering it in a ≈øweet di≈øpo≈øe, and well couching the Colours one within another. And in this ≈øitting, you perfect what only was rough before, by laying on the deep Colours, ≈øo that at the third ≈øitting, you may fini≈øh the Face, as in the Eyes, Eye-brows, Hair, and Ears, which things are the la≈øt work, and not to be perfected, till the Hair, Curtain, or Back-≈øide of the Picture, as al≈øo the Drapery be fini≈øhed. And of the≈øe ≈øittings in their Order.

div.head: The Operation of the fir≈øt ≈øitting, &c.
div.p: Having laid your ground for the general Complexion, the next work mu≈øt be to draw the out Lines, which you mu≈øt effect with Lake, and white mingled drawing very faintly; ≈øo that if you chance to mi≈øs your proportion, you may alter it with a deeper mixture of the ≈øame Colour.

Having drawn the proportion of the Face, add to the former Colour a ≈ømall proportion of red Lead, tempering it faintly to the Colour of the Cheeks, and Lips, at the tips of the Chin, and Ears, about the Eyes, and the roots of the Hair, placing the red ≈øhadows, and as for the ≈øhadows, they mu≈øt not be put in with the flat of the Pencil, but with ≈ømall touches after the manner
of hatching, and in this manner going over the Faces, you will cover your ground with the≈øe and the like Shadows, and in the≈øe dead Colours, your curio≈øity need not be great, only ≈øtrive to imitate Nature, as near, as may be, for the roughne≈øs of the Colours may be mended at the ≈øecond Operation.

Having duly placed, and proportioned your red ≈øhadows; in the next place, put in your faint blue ≈øhadows about the Corners of the Eyes, and Balls, &c and your greyi≈øh blue under the Eyes, and about the Temples, working them ≈øweetly and faintly over by degrees, heightning the ≈øhadow, as the Light falls; as likewi≈øe the hard ≈øhadows in the dark ≈øide of the Face under the Eye brows, No≈øe, Chin, and Neck, with ≈øome ≈øtronger touches on tho≈øe places, than on the light ≈øide of the Face, and ≈øo bring all your work together to an equal roundne≈øs, giving Perfection to no particular Part, at this time, but take a ful view of your object; and con≈øider, how near you hit the Life, not only in ≈øeeming likene≈øs but roundne≈øs, boldne≈øs of Po≈øture, colouring, and ≈øuch like. And having by this time wrought your fainter ≈øhadows into the red ≈øhadows, you may venture to take a touch at the hair, di≈øpo≈øing it in ≈øuch curls, folds, and forms, as you ≈øhall ≈øee convenient for Grace and Ornament, only drawing it with ≈øome Colour ≈øuitable to the Life, and fill up the empty ≈øpace with Colours, deepening it ≈øomewhat more ≈øtrongly, than before in the deepe≈øt ≈øhadowed places,
and this may ≈øuffice for the fir≈øt Operation.

div.head: The ≈øecond Operation or ≈øitting.
div.p: In this ≈øitting, the party mu≈øt take the ≈øame Place, and Po≈øture, as before, and then be curious to delineate with your Pencil, the particular varieties of Nature; and as you drew them over but rudely before, you now mu≈øt ≈øweeten them with the ≈øame Colours, by working, and driving them one into another; ≈øo that no rough edge, nor lump of Colour may appear, and this mu≈øt be done, with a Pencil ≈øharper than the former, by which means the ≈øhadow may be ≈øoft and ≈ømooth.

Thus having done, proceed to the back-≈øide of your Picture, and if there a Curtain, as is the u≈øual manner, be required, we will ≈øuppo≈øe it to be blue Sattin, and to do it, temper as much Bi≈øe in a ≈øhell, as will cover a ≈ømall Card, ≈øuffering it to be moi≈øt and well bound with Gum; then draw with your Pencil the outlines of your Curtain, as al≈øo of your Picture, and ≈øo lay it over very thin, and airy with a large Pencil, that it may be the whole ground, you intend to do with blue; and then lay it over again with a ≈øub≈øtantial body of the ≈øame Colour; in doing which, you mu≈øt be ≈øwift, keeping your Colour moi≈øt, and not ≈øuffering any part to be dry till all be covered.

If it happen that your Curtain is to be Crim≈øon, you mu≈øt trace it out with Lake, and lay the ground with a thin Colour, ob≈øerving where your ≈øtrong Lights and Reflections fall, there lay the Lights with a thin, and wateri≈øh Colour, and the Ground being yet wet, lay the ≈øtrong and hard ≈øhadows clo≈øe by the other Lights, with a dark Colour temper'd rea≈øonably thick.

Thus having layed your back-≈øide, which in the ≈øame manner you may do with any Colour. Your next work is, to lay your Linen of a fair white, and your Drapery flat with the Colour you intend it. Then take another view of the Face, and mark well what ≈øhadows are too light, or too deep, and endeavour to reduce each ≈øhadow to its due Perfection; then ≈øhadow the enterance into the Ear, and draw the Lines of the Eye lid, the deepne≈øs of the Eye brows, and all the mo≈øt eminent Notes and Marks in the Face, doing them with a very curious ≈øharp Pencil, and then heighten the Hair, deepening it, as it appears in the Life, ca≈øting over the ground ≈øome loo≈øe Hairs, which will look very plea≈øant, and make the Picture ≈øeem to ≈øtand at ≈øome di≈øtance from the Curtain.

In the ≈øhadowing your Linen, which ought to be very curious, u≈øe black, white, a little yellow, and a ≈ømall quantity of blue. The black being deepened with Ivory-black; to which add a ≈ømall quantity of lake, or Indico: And thus much for the ≈øecond Operation, from whence I proceed to the third and la≈øt.

div.head: The third Operation, &c.
div.p: In this, only ob≈øerve to give ≈øtrong touches, where you ≈øee Cau≈øe, or find any Defect, taking more perfect ob≈øervations for the rounding of the Face, which at this ≈øitting is better done than before, noting diligently, whatever may conduce to ≈øimilitude, which is the principal in the work; as Scars, Moles, ca≈øt with the Eyes, drawing the Mouth, &c.

In ca≈øe of Ornaments, as Garments, &c. the ground being laid with Bi≈øe; then the deepening mu≈øt be Lake, and Indico, the Lightning, white, very fine, faint and fair; and in the extreme light places, let what has been ≈øaid of the blue Drapery ≈øuffice, and may be under≈øtood of all other Colours; and for the greater Ornament, you may mix the Light with Gold, or Silver, &c.

If the Body is to be in Armour, lay liquid Silver for your ground, and when it is well dried and burni≈øhed, ≈øhadow it with Silver, Umber, and Indico, and work the ≈øhadow upon the Silver, as the life directs, &c.
For Gold Armour, lay liquid Gold for the ground, and ≈øhadow it with Engli≈øh Oker, Lake, and a mixture of Gold.
For Pearls, or that colour your ground mu≈øt be Indico, and white, and the ≈øhadow Pink, and black.

For Diamonds, lay a ground of liquid Silver deepened with Ivory and Cherry ≈øtone-black. And thus much for the Face, Body, &c. as to the laying in water Colour, and the next that pre≈øent them≈øelves are Landskips.

div.head: Directions for laying Landskips, &c.
div.p:
In this ca≈øe, always begin with the Sun Beams and Sky, the lighte≈øt part fir≈øt; and then the yellow, which mu≈øt be compo≈øed of Ma≈øticote, and white, the next your blue Skies with Smalt only leaving no part of your ground at fir≈øt uncovered; but lay the Colours ≈ømooth all over, working the Sky downward toward the Hori≈øon, ≈øtill ≈øuffering it to grow faint, &c. as it draws nearer the Earth, and work the tops of Mountains, and other objects very remote, ≈øo faint, that they may appear, as lo≈øt in the Air, and as for your lowe≈øt and neare≈øt ground, it mu≈øt be an Earth Colour of dark brown, inclining a little to yellowi≈øh, and green, as the matter requires, and the next a lighter green, and ≈øo ≈øucce≈ø≈øively, as they lo≈øe in their di≈øtance, you mu≈øt abate their Colour, nor mu≈øt you make any thing, you ≈øee at a great di≈øtance, perfect, or ab≈øolute, what it really is; becau≈øe it is altogether conjecture, you cannot ab≈øolutely di≈øcern it, but expre≈øs it in Colours weakly, and faintly, as your Eye judges it may be. And ever ob≈øerve in this ca≈øe to place the light again≈øt the dark; and ≈øo con≈øequently, the contrary, which is an excellent
way, to extend the Pro≈øpect far off, yet do it ≈øo, as the ≈øhadows may lo≈øe in their proportion of di≈øtance, by degrees, their force, as they remove from the Eye, ob≈øerving further, that the ≈øtronge≈øt ≈øhadow mu≈øt ever be neare≈øt. And thus much may ≈øuffice for limning in water Colours, which if duly ob≈øerved, and practi≈øed, will wonderfully help the Learner: And in this manner, you may paint upon Gla≈øs, by laying on the faire≈øt Colours if it appear through the Gla≈øs fir≈øt; but if otherwi≈øe, lay fir≈øt a ground, and e≈øpecially upon Copper.

div.head: CHAP. X. Directions for the mo≈øt curious Painting, or Limning in Oil, with the various Colours, and materials required on that occa≈øion, with their manner of preparing, and ordering; as al≈øo In≈øtructions to paint to the Life, &c. wonderfully plea≈øing, and much profitable to be known, as well by the Gentry, and others, as tho≈øe that intend it for their Profe≈ø≈øion.
div.p:
AS this Noble Science, in all Ages, has been held in much E≈øteem, and Veneration among Men, in all Ages, it is now more e≈øpecially
covered to be known, and practi≈øed, by either Sex; wherefore for the better In≈øtruction, e≈øpecially of the Learner, I have thought fit to lay down the following plain, and ea≈øie rules, which being well ob≈øerved, and practi≈øed, may in time bring him to be a great Ma≈øter in the Science. But fir≈øt, of the Colours to be u≈øed on this occa≈øion, without knowing which, the re≈øt may prove ineffectual.

The blacks are Lamp-black. Sea coal-black, Char-coal black, Ivory-black, and Earth of Collen. The white white Lead only The greens, Verdegrea≈øe, Terra-yert, and Verditer. The yellows are Pink, Ma≈øticote, Orpiment, Spruce Oker, Engli≈øh Oker. The blues are Bi≈øe, Smalt, Indico, and Ultramarine. The reds are Vermilion, red Lead, Indian red, Lake, and Ornotto. The Colours indifferent are Spani≈øh brown, burnt Spruce, and Umber.

The≈øe are the principal Colours to be laid in Oil, and mu≈øt for the greate≈øt part of them be ground upon your flat ≈øtone with a Muller, with Line-≈øeed Oil, though as for Ivory, Spruce, Oker, and Umber, they mu≈øt be burnt before they are ground. And as for Ma≈øticote, Ultramarine, Verditer, Vermilion, Lamp-black, Smalt, and Orpiment, you may temper them upon your Pallet with Oil, ≈øaving your ≈øelf the labour of grinding, &c. and as for tho≈øe, that are to be burnt you mu≈øt perform it in a Crucible, and though Line-≈øeed Oil be common to all, yet in ca≈øe, with your white Lead; you are to
lay Linen, you mu≈øt mix it with Oil of Wall nuts by rea≈øon the other will in a ≈øhort time turn yellowi≈øh.

The next thing, you are to take care of, is to have good Pencils of all ≈øizes, a Pallet, or Board, to lay your Colours on, whil≈øt you are u≈øing them, and an Ey≈øil to lay your Cloth upon, or again≈øt, and a ≈øtraining Frame, to which it mu≈øt be nailed, and you mu≈øt further have a Stay or Mole≈øtick, which is made of Braziel, or ≈øuch Wood, as will not ea≈øily bend, about a yard long, at one end of which, tie a ball of Cotton in a piece of Leather; ≈øo that holding it in your left hand again≈øt the work, you may ≈øupport your right Arm with it, whil≈øt you are working; and being thus furni≈øhed, you may proceed to the work, &c. And fir≈øt of the Complexion.

div.head: For a fair Complexion.
div.p: Take a ≈ømall quantity of white, and twice as much Vermilion, and Lake, temper the≈øe with the flat of a Knife's Blade upon your Pallet, or Hand-board, and u≈øe it for the deepe≈øt Carnation of the Face, adding moreover to a ≈ømall part of it more white, and re≈øerve that for a lighter Carnation. And yet another part being re≈øerved, add more white to it, till it come to the lighte≈øt Colour in the Face: And then proceed to prepare the faint ≈øhadows, and in doing it.

Take Smalt, and mix it with a little white, which may conveniently ≈øerve for the Eyes; then laying a≈øide the greate≈øt quantity, add to the re≈øt a little Pink, and the≈øe well tempered, will ≈øerve for the faint greeni≈øh ≈øhadow in the Face; then proceed to prepare your deep ≈øhadows: And in order to it, take Lake, Pink, and Ivory-black a like quantity of each, and temper them together. And if the Face of the Party, or the Figure you are to copy require redder ≈øhadows, than what you have tempered, add more Lake, if yellower, more Pink, if bluer, or greyer, then add more black.

Thus having prepared your Pallet with Colours ≈øuitable to a fair Face; con≈øider again, in ca≈øe the Complexion be more brown, or ≈øwarthy, you may temper the Colours, as before, putting moreover a little quantity of burnt Oker among≈øt your Lake, Vermilion, and White, that it may look ≈øomewhat tawny among≈øt your heightned Colours: In this ca≈øe, temper a little Oker, ≈øo much only, as will ju≈øt turn it, and for your very deep, and very faint ≈øhadows, you may u≈øe the ≈øame, as for the former Complexion.
For a tawny Complexion, u≈øe the ≈øame, in the general, as before, only let the ≈øhadows be prepared of burnt Oker, and Umber.

For an ab≈øolute black Complexion, your dark ≈øhadow mu≈øt be as the fore going, but as for your heightnings, you mu≈øt take burnt Oker, Lake, with black and white, yet but a little of
the latter mu≈øt be put in at fir≈øt, that you may the better work it up by degrees: And note, that the ≈øingle Colours laid at fir≈øt upon your Pallet well tempe ‚Ä¢ ed, according to the fore-going Directions, ≈øerve for ≈øhadows for all Complexions.

div.head: CHAP. XI. What Pencils are to be u≈øed in painting a Face, and how to di≈øpo≈øe them. Directions to paint a Face in Oil Colour, and what mixtures are requi≈øite for Carments, &c.
div.p:
YOur Pencils, how ≈ømall ≈øoever, ought to have a ≈øtick about nine inches long, cut, or ≈øharpened at the farthe≈øt end into a point, and when you are to draw any Face, lay together two Ducks Quills Fitch-Pencils, two Goo≈øe Quill fitch'd, two pointed, and two bri≈øtled, the pairs being exactly alike; and when you are to u≈øe them, having your Pallet in a readine≈øs upon your thumb, take them in your right Hand, and put the ends of your ≈øticks into your left Hand, keeping when you work the hairy ends, at a di≈øtance le≈øt the Colours intermingle, & ≈øo proceed to your work, viz. your Cloth being ready primed, and ≈øtrained upon your Frame, ≈øcrape it
over with a Knifes edge, not very ≈øharp, to take off the knots, if any appear, and ≈øo ≈øet your Frame and Cloth upon your Ey≈øel a convenient height, ≈øo that you ≈øitting upon a Stool level with the Party or Copy you draw, may the better have the Picture equal, &c. placing it according to your Light, as I have directed in Water-limning; then with a piece of Chalk draw the proportion of the Face upon the Cloth, making the place for the Eyes, No≈øe, Mouth, Ears, Hair, &c. Then take a Swans Quill pointed Pencil, and begin with ≈øome of the lighte≈øt Colours in the lighte≈øt part of the Face (the Cloth before being primed, or groundlaid) as the heightning of the Fore-head, Cheekbone, No≈øe, &c. on the lighte≈øt ≈øide, and when you have done that, next proceed to the mean parts, viz. tho≈øe not altogether ≈øo light, as the Cheek bone of the fore-≈øhortning, or dark ≈øide, the Chin and upper Lip and by degrees come to the redde≈øt part of all.

Having thus far proceeded, lay the greeni≈øh faint ≈øhadows in places convenient, and where you ≈øee cau≈øe, to moderate the harder ≈øhadows; but have e≈øpecial regard not to place the green, where the red ≈øhould be: And ≈øo, all the faint, and light beginnings being put in, take a Ducks Quill fitch'd, and a Goo≈øe-Quill pointed Pencil, and begin at the Eyes to ≈øhadow with Lake, and trace out tho≈øe parts of the Face therewith, that require it, as the Eyes, No≈øe, Mouth, the compa≈øs of the Ears, &c. and do
this before you lay on any Colour, lightly wiping it over with a linen rag, to prevent theovercoming of other Colours.

Having now put in all the Colours, dark, and light, take a large fitched Pencil, and ≈øweeten the Colours: That is, go over the ≈øeveral ≈øhadows with a clean, ≈øoft Pencil, which by a gentle, and dexterous handling, will force, or drive the Colours into each other; ≈øo that they will repre≈øent the laying on at once, and not at ≈øeveral times. This being done, begin again with your clean Pencils of ≈øuch bigne≈øs, as the work requires; then, the Party ≈øitting in the po≈øture as before, take a curious view, and ≈øee what defects you find in the work, and amend them; after that proceed to heighten, or deepen your ≈øhadows, as the Nature of the piece requires, and if a Beard, or Hair be required, take a Goo≈øe Quill bri≈øtle Pencil, and put in the Hair about the Face, and rub in the greater Hair, with the greater Bri≈øtle, heightning it up with your Goo≈øe-quill Pencil, and ≈øo your work is done.

If Garments are required, called by Arti≈øts Drapery, For a red Garment, lay dead Colour with Vermilion, glaze it over with Lake, and heighten it with white. For Scarlet, Vermilion mu≈øt be the lighte≈øt, deepened with Lake, or Indian red. For a crim≈øon Velvet, lay burnt Oker, Vermilion, or Indian red, glaze it with Lake, and touch it up with Vermilion. For a ≈øad red, heighten Indian red with white, and
let all your deepenings be with black, Pink, and Lake well tempered. For green Garments, heighten Bi≈øe and Pink with Ma≈øticote, and deepen it with Indico and Pink. For green Velvet, lay the dead Colour with white, and a little Lamp black, glaze it with Verdegrea≈øe, deepen it with Indico and Pink, and heighten it with Pink and white. For yellow, take yellow Oker, Ma≈øticote, and Umber, lay the dead Colour with Ma≈øticote, and white, in the highe≈øt Places, and with white, and Oker in the meane≈øt, and with Umber in the darke≈øt, glazing it when dry with Pink.

For blue Garments, take Indico, and white, laying fir≈øt the white in its due Places; and then your mean Colour, viz. Indico, and white well tempered in their due places; then deepen it with Indico, and glaze it with Ultramarine when dry, &c.
For purple Garments, take Oil ≈ømall tempered with Lake, and white Lead, and heighten it with the latter.

For black Garments, let the dead Colour be Lamp-black, and a little Verdegrea≈øe, and when it is dry, go over it with Ivory-black, and having heightned it with white, go over it with Ivory black, and Verdegrea≈øe.

For Orange Colour Garments, mix red Lead, and Lake, laying the lighte≈øt parts with red Lead, and white; the mean parts with only red Lead, and the deeper with Lake, and if need requires you may heighten it with white.

For Cloth coloured Garments, for the ground, take Umber, and white, and for the deeper ≈øhadows Umber and black, and for the mean Umber and Oker, and whiten it with Oker, and white. And thus much may ≈øuffice for limning, and painting of the≈øe kinds.

div.head: CHAP. XII. The curious and my≈øterious Art of etching, and ingraving in Gold, Silver, Copper, Steel, &c. di≈øplayed, and made manife≈øt in ea≈øie and plain Rules, and Methods, by which an unexperienced Per≈øon, many attain to the knowledge thereof, and the expert be wonderfully improved, &c.
div.p: TO introduce this curious Art, I think it highly convenient to begin with etching, the better to give a light into what ≈øucceeds, &c. and fir≈øt of the Ground.

In this ca≈øe, procure three parts of Virgins wax, and one of A≈øphaltum, one part of Ma≈øtick, and one part of clarified Ro≈øin, but all but the Wax, putting that into a new glazed Pipkin, or Pan, and let it boil over a gentle Fire, at what time, put the other Ingredients to it, which
being melted, pour it out into fair cold water, keeping back the dregs; and when it is cold, work it into a ball; tie it then in a rag, ≈øo clo≈øe, that no dregs may come through, and u≈øe it upon your Copper, as you have occa≈øion.

In preparing your Copper, ob≈øerve that it be well poli≈øhed, not lying higher in one place than another, nor no where uneven, and if you e≈øpy and ≈øpecks or di≈øorders in it, coal it over with a well burnt Char-coal, and fair water, and ≈øet it a≈ølope to dry, which done, ≈øcrape ≈øome very dry Chalk or Whitening upon it, and rub it over with a woollen rag, not touching the Face of the Plate with your finger, till the ground be laid, which mu≈øt be done in this manner, viz.

Put lighted Small coal into a Chafing-di≈øh, and lay the Plate on the wrong ≈øide over it, that a gentle breathing of heat may come through; then take your ground in the rag, and rub i ‚Ä¢ gently up and down the Copper, till it coming through the covering, by rea≈øon of the heat, may ≈øufficiently cover the Plate, not too thick, nor too thin; and then whil≈øt it is warm, take a Duck's Feather, and ≈ømooth it to an exact evenne≈øs, but beware the Copper be not too hot, for if it ≈ømoak, the moi≈øture of the ground is gone, and then in etching, it will crack, and fly up; and when it is according to your mind, ≈øuffer the Plate to cool; then grind a piece of white Lead in Gum-water, not very ≈øtiff, and make th ‚Ä¢ white of convenient ≈øtiffne≈øs to wa≈øh over th ‚Ä¢ fir≈øt ground of the Plate, with a bru≈øh dippe ‚Ä¢
therein, till you perceive it every way ≈ømooth, going over it with another bru≈øh of ≈øoft Furs, and ≈øo let it dry.

The ground thus laid, take your draught, after which, you are to work, and ≈øcrape on the back-≈øide of it ≈øome red Chalk, moving it all over, and ≈øcrape over that ≈øome Small coal, very fine, ≈øuffering it to mingle with the Chalk; and then with a Pencil, or Hand-bru≈øh, rub it up and down, till it be ≈ømooth, and even, and ≈øo place your de≈øign upon the Plate, and with a blunt Needle, or Steel Point, draw over the out≈øtroaks; and then you mu≈øt have ≈øeveral Needles, according to the ≈ømallne≈øs, and largene≈øs of your ≈øtroaks in the Copy, and with them in a ‚Ä¢ in Pencil, frame, or ≈øtick according as bluntne≈øs, or ≈øharpne≈øs requires, take out all the black ≈øtroaks, pre≈ø≈øing ≈øo hard, that the needles may pa≈øs through the ground, and make ≈øome ≈ømall Impre≈ø≈øion on the Copper, ever ob≈øerving when ‚Ä¢ ou lay by your Plate, to wrap it up in a Paper „Äà‚óä„Äâ prevent ≈øcratches, or the Air ≈øpoiling the Ground, wiping away as you work the Ground ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e needles brake up with a light Pencil, not ≈øuffering the ground to lye too long on the Plate before you fini≈øh, for the Air drawing out the noi≈øture of the ground, the Etching will appear ‚Ä¢ road and deep, working of black and un≈øeemly; „Äà‚óä„Äâ when ≈øometimes you ≈øuppo≈øe it eaten ≈øufficiently, you will find it defective in many places, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d in fro≈øty weather you mu≈øt wrap the plate as well in a blanket as in a Paper, for if the fro≈øt
take the Copper, the ground will ≈øtart from it, and ≈øo the Aqua-fortis will ≈øpread under it, and keep no certain form.

Having ob≈øerved the≈øe directions, take green Wax, and melt it in a new Pan, or Pipkin, and with a Pencil cover the edges of the Copper and ≈øtick the Wax round about like a Wall, to keep in the Aqua-fortis; that done, which being firmly ≈øtuck on, take the third part of an ounce of Aqua-fortis, and break it with other Water of the ≈øame kind, that has been once, or twice u≈øed, taking at lea≈øt two parts of the old, to one part of new, and in ca≈øe, you have no old Aqua-fortis, then in≈øtead of it, u≈øe ≈øtrong white-wine Vinegar, as a mixture; and for ≈øuch Figures, or things, as you would have lye fine, and ≈øweet, you mu≈øt pour out your Aqua-fortis into ≈øome Earthen Ve≈ø≈øel; and then wa≈øh of what remains with fair water, and ≈øuffer it to dry; then melt Candle-grea≈øe, with a little ground, and with a Pencil cover the Places you would have ly ‚Ä¢ faint; then pour on again your Aqua-fortis, and ≈øo continue to do, as often, as you can co ‚Ä¢
ceive it convenient, then melt off the ground over a gentle Fire, and with a clean rag, wipe it off, and you will have the perfect impre≈ø≈øion of the Copy on the Plate, which you may work of at the rowling Pre≈øs, to ≈øerve your occa≈øions, and thus you may do upon any metal the wate ‚Ä¢ will take, &c.

From etching, I proceed to the Art of engraving, and he that would be expert herein, mu≈ø ‚Ä¢
have a regard to true drawing; wherefore, I would advi≈øe the unskilful well to con≈øider what I have laid down of that kind, and ≈øo provide him≈øelf with materials for the performance of this curious Art.

In the fir≈øt place, be ≈øure to choo≈øe a good Oil ≈øtone free from pin-holes, or flaws, not too hard, nor too ≈øoft; and therefore the better to furni≈øh your ≈øelf aright, you mu≈øt con≈øult, in what the ≈øtre≈øs of your bu≈øine≈øs will lie; for if you intend Picture, or Letter work, accounted more curious than Marks, or Arms u≈øed by Gold-≈ømiths, and Pewterers, you mu≈øt have your Gravers accordingly ≈øhaped, and tempered, for Gold-≈ømiths, &c. Gravers are frequently crooked, the better to come at hollow places, &c. but for Copper, or any Plate, that may be ea≈øily come at, the ≈øtrait Gravers are ever held the be≈øt, and if you ≈øu≈øpect their goodne≈øs, try whether, or not, they are file proof; and if ≈øo, they will fit your purpo≈øe, though at fir≈øt, by rea≈øon of their temper, they may appear brittle, and ≈øometimes break ≈øhort, yet being ground out, they will ≈øtill grow better and better, and come in a little time to an excellent temper.

As for the forms of Gravers, as to their u≈øe, the ≈øquare one makes a broad ≈øhadow ≈øtroak, or hatch and that which is, form Lozenge, a narrow deep one, the one being appropriated to large, and the other to fine ≈øtroaks, yet if your work be curious, a middle ≈øize between the≈øe will the better accomodate you, which will render
your ≈øtroaks, or hatches more graceful, and yet carry with them ≈øufficient force and vigor.

In ca≈øe of whetting your Gravers, which is frequently required, pour a little fine Olive Oil upon your ≈øtone, and laying that ≈øide, which you intend ≈øhall cut the Copper flat upon it, whet it very flat, and even, and to that purpo≈øe, carry your hand very ≈øteady, continuing an equal ≈øtrength, and placing your fore finger firm upon the contrary ≈øide, ≈øo that you may have more power to guide it with exactne≈øs; then turn the unwhetted ≈øide, and u≈øe it in the ≈øame form and manner, that there may be a very ≈øharp edge; then turning uppermo≈øt that edge, which in the former manner you have whetted, ≈øetting the end of your Graver obliquely upon the ≈øtone, bear your hand with an exact evenne≈øs, to the intent it may prove very flat, and ≈ø ‚Ä¢ oping in the form of a Lozenge; and in this, you mu≈øt take great care, for if your Graver be not well, and rightly whetted, you can never grave well.

Ob≈øerve, when you have a Graver, who≈øe handle is a round, or oval knob, if you would prevent it from running into the Copper, or other metal you grave, further than is convenient; then mu≈øt you cut off that part of the knob, which lies in a Line with the point of the Graver, and make it as level as you can with the point; nor then will it hinder your Hand from carrying an even ≈øtroak, which otherwi≈øe it will do, e≈øpecially in working a great Plate, by bearing too much upon the Copper, and in holding
it, place the knob-≈øide, or that part of the Ball not cut off in the hollow of your Hand, extending your fore-finger towards the point, and laying it oppo≈øite to the edge, that is to cut, and place your other fingers on the one ≈øide of the handle, and your thumb on the other ≈øide of the Graver, in ≈øuch a manner, as with ea≈øe you may guide it flat and parallel with the Plate, being ever very careful, that you fingers do not interpo≈øe between the Plate, and Graver, le≈øt it hinder you in carrying it level with the Plate, hindering you from making your ≈øtroaks with freedom, and neatne≈øs.

Further to fix you in this affair, you mu≈øt have a ≈øtrong round Cu≈øhion of Leather filled with fine Sand, about half a foot over, and four inches in the Diameter, ri≈øing a little in the middle, and ≈øloping towards the brims, but not much, and this mu≈øt be to lay your Plate on, that you may turn it at lei≈øure; and if you are to make ≈øtreight ≈øtroaks, hold your Graver in a direct Line: Or in ca≈øe you would have your ≈øtroaks broader, and deeper in one place than in another, you mu≈øt lay more or le≈øs ≈øtre≈øs, as you ≈øee occa≈øion, ob≈øerving in all ≈øtreight ≈øtroaks, to hold your Plate ≈øteady, and firm upon the Cu≈øhion, and the Table, or Bank on which it ≈øtands well fixed: But in crooked, and winding ≈øtroaks, you mu≈øt hold your Hand, and Graver ≈øteadfa≈øt, and only turn your Plate, or otherways you cannot command your Hand to that neatne≈øs, as in many ca≈øes is required, ob≈øerving
at the ≈øame time, for the more ≈øteadine≈øs to keep your Elbow fixed upon the Table, and your Eye on the Plate, ≈øcraping your work, as you go with the edge of a burni≈øher to take off the roughne≈øs; yet be careful that you make no ≈øcratches, and the better to ≈øee what you have done, rub the place over with a piece of black felt dipped in Oil; and then if any ≈øcratches appear, with your burni≈øher rub them out, and if any ≈øtroaks be too hard, in the ≈øame manner you may make them fainter. And in ca≈øe your Graver ≈øhould happen to appear very hard, which by its exce≈ø≈øive brittlene≈øs in often breaking is known, lay it upon a burning Charcoal, till it grow yellow; and then dip it in water, and it will by often ≈øo doing render it of a better temper, but if it be blunt in a ≈øhort time cutting, then it is too ≈øoft, and you mu≈øt heat it in the fire, and dip it in Lime juice, or Vinegar: And thus much for the management of the Tools. &c. the which by a little practice will ≈øoon grow natural.

Another material thing in Art is to be con≈øidered; which is, to take the Impre≈ø≈øion you are to cut, or grave upon your Plate; and in this ca≈øe, heat your Plate over a fire of Small-coal, and having a piece of fine Bees-wax tyed up in a fine rag, worked like a ball, that it may ≈øit clo≈øe, wipe the Plate over with it, when it is hot enough, very lightly, till you perceive it is covered with wax, very thin, and even, laying it with a feather, in which, at fir≈øt you may find ≈øome difficulty, but u≈øe will render it ea≈øie,
and in this ca≈øe, if you are to imitate an exact Copy, it mu≈øt be ≈øo ordered, that it may ≈øtand the contrary way on the Plate; and therefore in con≈øideration hereof, your be≈øt way will be to track it over with a black Lead Pencil; e≈øpecially in ca≈øe of a very old Picture, which being done, take a piece of poli≈øhed Ivory, and placing your Picture exactly on your Plate the Print fide downward, rub it lightly, and you will perceive the exact proportion of the Print remaining upon the Wax, or the Plate; then take a ≈øteel point, and go over each particular Limb, &c. e≈øpecially in the out ≈øtroaks, and there will be but little difficulty to mark the ≈øhadows which he before you, as you engrave the Work, and the readier it will be, if ≈øo you note how far your ≈øhadows ≈øhould be dark, and how far light, with your black Lead before you rub it off.

The carrying of the hand in this kind, will at fir≈øt ≈øeem difficult, as to the depth of your ≈øtroaks; but in general, ob≈øerve ever to carry your hand with ≈øuch a ≈ølight, that you may end with the ≈øame faintne≈øs, or darkne≈øs you begin: And in ca≈øe, one part require more deepne≈øs, and blackne≈øs than another, you mu≈øt do that by degrees; and that you may the more expertly do it, ob≈øerve that your ≈øtroaks be not too clo≈øe, nor too wide; and therefore to bring your hand in the better, practi≈øe at fir≈øt by ≈øuch Prints, as are but loo≈øly ≈øhadowed, lea≈øt by attempting to imitate tho≈øe more dark and clo≈øe, you happen to be puzzled where to begin, and
where to end, but practice will inform you.

As for Letters; in ca≈øe of Copies, the Letters mu≈øt be gone over with ungumed Ink, or with black Lead, and laid on the Plate when waxed as the former, unle≈øs you are ≈øo dexterous at writing, that you can draw them by hand, or with a ≈øteel point on the Plate in true Cut, &c.

But if a Map, or other Mathematical In≈øtrument be required, every circle, or perpendicular mu≈øt be drawn over as before, or you cannot exactly imitate. But in ca≈øe of a face, or coat of Arms, or In≈øtruments not to be printed; then you may black over the back-≈øide, as in etching, but you mu≈øt u≈øe for engraving a wax ground only.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. The Mystery of cutting in Wood, laying Gold, or Silver, ≈øolid, or liquid, preparing Colours for the painting of Pictures, or Prints, the way of refre≈øhing old Paintings, or Pictures; colouring Maps, Buildings, Landskips, and many other curious things, and matters.
As for cutting in Wood, in relation to Pictures or the like.
div.p: YOU mu≈øt prepare your Wood in the manner of a Plate, though an Inch thick, or according as the de≈øign requires, either Box, or Pear-tree, rendering it by plaining as ≈ømooth, and level as a piece of Paper; which done, having a d ‚Ä¢ aught of your de≈øign, you mu≈øt rub the Wood gently over with a ground of pa≈øte made of the fine≈øt flower; and then fix your draught, or copy upon it, when ≈øuffering it to dry, rub the back ≈øide of the paper, which mu≈øt be uppermo≈øt, with your wet finger, till you crumble it off ≈øo thin, that the Print plainly appears upon the Wood, as if it had been pa nted, or drawn thereon with a p ‚Ä¢ n, or pencil.

Having thus prepared your Wood, if it be ≈ømall, fa≈øten it up with coins, that it move not, unle≈øs there be occa≈øion, or as the ≈øtroaks require
and then having a fine ≈ømall knife in the nature of a Pen-knife, but much le≈øs and thinner, e≈øpecially for the fine ≈øtroaks, cut out all the white ≈øtroaks, and ground, and ≈øuffer the black ones to ≈øtand, ≈øharpening the fine ≈øtroaks, and bringing them to an edge, that they may not print black, or dull; and above all, be ≈øure to do it with ≈øo light, and curious a hand, that you break none of them; for if ≈øo, you much deface, and injure the Work, they not being to be repaired, and further ob≈øerve to leave a good foundation to the ≈øtroaks, though never ≈øo fine at the top, lea≈øt by the force of the Pre≈øs, they break in working.

div.head: To write, or gild with Gold, and Silv ‚Ä¢ r, an ea≈øec, and curious method, &c.
div.p:
If you would have fair Letters appear in Gold, or Silver, take Gum-armoniack, and grind it with a little juice of Garlick, and put thereto a few drops of the weak water of Gum-arabick; and ≈øo make it to the thickne≈øs of Ink, that you may conveniently write with it; and ≈øo write, or draw what you think convenient, and ≈øuffer it to dry a little, but not too much, le≈øt it take not the Gold, or Silver, nor too little, le≈øt it drown them. Then lay your Gold, or Silver in Leaf
upon a Leather Cu≈øhion, being a piece of Calves skin ≈øtuffed, with the ‚Ä¢ ough ≈øide outwards; and ≈øo with a ≈øharp knife, cut it into what proportion you will, ≈øuitable to what you have written, and taking it up with a loo≈øe piece of Cotton Wool, on which you have breathed, cover with it the place intended, pre≈ø≈øing it down hard, and where the Gum-water is, it will take it; then bru≈øh away with other Cotton, what it has not taken, and being dry, burni≈øh it with a piece of poli≈øhed Ivory, and it will appear very ≈øplendid.

div.head: To write, or gild with liquid Gold, or Silver, &c.
div.p: Take ≈øhell Gold, which is made of the raggid edges, or c ‚Ä¢ ttings of Leaf Gold; and when you are de≈øirous to u≈øe it, put in a little fair water, tempering it up with a clean Pencil, and lay it on with a Pen, or Pencil in what form you plea≈øe, either by way of writing, or gilding, and when it is dry, rub it over with a Dog's, Call's, or Hor≈øe's Fore-tooth, and it will be very ≈øhining, and plea≈øant. div.head: How to prepare Colours to colour printed Pictures, and thereby render them beautiful.
div.p: For a curious Violet Colour, take Turn≈øole, being a dye infu≈øed into a piece of a linen rag, heat it in Vinegar, and it will give you the Colour de≈øired, after which di≈ø≈øolve in it ≈øome Gum-arabick, and u≈øe it, as you ≈øee occa≈øion.
For a curious yellow, take Gum-booge, and di≈ø≈øolve it in fair Spring water over a gentle fire.

To make a tran≈øparent red, take Braziel, grind it, and heat it over a Fire, with ≈ømall Beer, and Vinegar, put in a little Powder of Alum, and Gum-arabick, and ≈øuffer it to boil, till it ta≈øte ≈øtrong, &c.
