For a curious blue, take fine Litmos, and cut it into ≈ømall peices, lay it for the ≈øpace of twenty four hours in a weak Lake, Gum-water; to make which, you have been before directed, and it will an≈øwer your expectations.
To make a curious green, take the juice of rue, and a little Verdigrea≈øe.
For a light green, take Sap green flower de Bi≈øs, or tawny green, and ≈øteep them in fair water.
To ≈øhadow greens, ≈øleep Indico, and yellow Berries.
To ≈øhadow blues, take Litmos, and Indico, ≈øteeping them in the Lees of Sope a≈øhes, and u≈øe them with Gum water.
To make a good brown, take Ceru≈øe, red Lead, Pink, and Engli≈øh Oker, mixing them, with Gum-water.
For an Orange Colour, take red Lead, and yellow Berries, and mix them with Gum-water.
For a curious fle≈øh Colour, take white Lead red Lead, and Lake with Gum-water.
To make a Colour for precious ≈øtones, take Verdigrea≈øe, and Varni≈øh for an Emrald, Florence Lake, for a Ruby, and Ultramarine, for Sapphire.

div.head: How to colour Map, and what is to be ob≈øerved therein.
div.p: In this ca≈øe as well as in other printed Pictures, is no more than to ≈øet them out in their proper Colours, which you mu≈øt accordingly con≈øider, as the nature of the thing requires, it being impo≈ø≈øible to direct in particulars; however ob≈øerve that water mu≈øt be a faint blue, Sky ≈øomewhat deeper, Trees green, Hou≈øes in Maps are u≈øually red and ways yellow, and green: And to the≈øe, and the re≈øt, ≈øuit any water Colour, you think ≈øuitable mentioned in this Book.

div.head: Colouring for Landskips, and building at large, very proper.
div.p: In Landskips, for the ≈øaddo≈øt Hills, u≈øe burnt Umber, for the lighte≈øt, put ≈øome yellow to it, and for other Hills, lay Copper green thickened on the Fire, or in the Sun, and for tho≈øe further off, mix with it ≈øome yellow Berries, and let the fourth part be done with green Verditer; and the furthe≈øt, and fainte≈øt Places with blue Bi≈øe, for the lighte≈øt places, u≈øe white, and ≈øhadow it with blue, as for the High ways, do them with white, and red Lead, u≈øing for Variety yellow Oker, ≈øhadowing it with burnt Umber; and it may likewi≈øe be u≈øed for ≈øandy Rocks, and Hills; and as for other Rocks, you may lay them with ≈øeveral Colours; but at a di≈øtance, they mu≈øt appear, blue, as in the Air; as for the water, do it with black Verditer, and white ≈øhadowed with green, and with blue Verditer, when the banks ca≈øt a green ≈øhadow upon the water; but when the water is dark in the ≈øhadows, ≈øhadow it with Indico, blue Verditer, and green, &c.

div.head: How to colour Building, &c.
div.p:
In colouring Buildings, you mu≈øt u≈øe much variety the better to ≈øet them off, yet not ≈øo, as they may appear extravagantly adorned, or contrary to the u≈øe of this kind; but for Walls, and Conduits,
u≈øe a mixture of white, and black; as likewi≈øe for other materials, but if a Brick-hou≈øe, u≈øe red Lead, and white, and where the Hou≈øes ≈øtand thick together, there u≈øe ≈øundry Colours ≈øuitable to the occa≈øion.

div.head: T ‚Ä¢ clean≈øe old Pictures, and render them fair and plea≈øing.
div.p: Take Wood-A≈øhes, the white≈øt that may be had, ≈øift them through a fine lawn ≈øieve, and with a Spunge, and fair water, wa≈øh the Picture gently over not rubbing it hard, lea≈øt you impair the ≈øhadows, which being done, and the Picture dry, take di≈øtilled Varni≈øh, and rub it thin, and gently over, and it will create a la≈øting fre≈øhne≈øs, or for want of this, you may do it with the whites of Eggs exceeding well beaten, or with Gum-water: But note, the Pictures to be thus u≈øed, mu≈øt be ≈øuch as are laid in Water-Colour Oil.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. In≈øtructions for re≈øtoring Tape≈øtry Hangings, Carpets, or Turky Chairs, that are faded, or decayed, to their lively Colour; to prepare Flock Cloth for Hangings; Spani≈øh white, Size, Alum water, and Gum-arabick water, how to make them; as al≈øo to thicken Cloth for Screens, &c.
To refre≈øh Hangings, or Tape≈øtry, Carpets, or Chairs,

CHAP. I. Metals, and Minerals, their Quality, and Generation, from what they proceed, and how produc'd, the ‚Ä¢ rt of tran≈ømuting, and making artificial Metals, or Minerals, with other material matters.
div.p:
IN ca≈øe of Minerals, and all things inanimate, concenter'd, or contained in the Bowels of the Earth, it is convenient to reduce them to four kinds of Mixtures, viz. Metals, Stones, Earth, or Juices, Nature producing them with mixture, and participation of each o ‚Ä¢ her, and here by Earth. I mean the ≈øimple Element only, of which, as the Philo≈øophers affirm, all ≈øublunary Bodies are compounded, and though the Earth,
according to the ≈øituations of Countries, and differences of Climes, differs in Scent, Colour and Ta≈øte; yet that proceeds from a mixture of ≈øome other part, or effect of the former; the pure Elementary Earth being in all places one and the ≈øame; in which, and by the operation of heat and moi≈øture, the others are generated; and as there are more or le≈øs of the≈øe, the Metals are finer or cour≈øer: But to come nearer to our purpo≈øe.

Gold is found in Grains, or Sand; and Silver in veins, and ≈øometimes twi≈øted, and wreathed like the branches of a Vine, and at other times the≈øe Metals are found in ≈øtones, with who≈øe hardne≈øs, they have incorporated them≈øelves, and being broken, are with fining materials extracted. As for Gold; it is the mo≈øt perfect of all inanimate bodies, and has its Generation, as I have ≈øaid from heat, and moi≈øture in the Original; but of Parts ≈øo well contracted, and compacted by Concoction, that it is in a manner incorruptible, it being beyond the Power of any Element to prejudice, or de≈øtroy it; for the Fire of the mo≈øt ≈øubtle, and piercing Quality, con≈øuming all other Metals by long Application, renders Gold more pure, nor can the Air, Water, or Earth dimini≈øh its lu≈øter; but that it will again recover it, by which means, it has de≈øerved the E≈øtimation the World affords it; and is ≈øo ductil, that being expanded, an ounce of pure Gold will cover a place of twenty, or thirty feet ≈øquare.

Silver as is hinted, carries a finene≈øs next to Gold, wanting little more than the Colour, to be brought to its perfection; wherefore tho≈øe that ≈øtrongly inveigh again≈øt the tran≈ømutation of Metals, have been convinced, that there is a po≈ø≈øibility to turn Silver into Gold, by rea≈øon Fire and artificial concoctions may ≈øupply the defect, of which there have been many Experiments, and from the even mixture, good temperature, and finene≈øs of its parts, it is not only ductil, and malleable, but endures the Fire with little wa≈øte, and admirable it is, that an ounce of fine Silver may be drawn out into a thou≈øand four hundred yards, and that too, for the mo≈øt part without breaking; and all this exten≈øion may be gilded with ≈øix grains of Gold.

Copper is a metal to the compo≈øition whereof, a great quantity of Sulphur is required, and from a di≈øtempered heat in the mixture, the fiery heat proceeds, and being over burnt in its compo≈øition, it is therefore le≈øs ≈øubject to Corruption, and is u≈øed about Engines of long continuance, becau≈øe it ru≈øteth not, and is found in Mineral Stones of divers colours, though the mo≈øt effectual Colour is green, or blue, and ≈øo often is it ingendred near Gold, and Silver, that many times following a vein of it, much pure Gold, and oftener Silver has been found; and ≈øuch Veins of Copper, as make a ≈øuperficial ≈øhew, are upon being digged, richer the deeper you go, and that is occa≈øioned by the moi≈øture; and many times pure Silver is at the bottom, &c.

Iron though very common, which le≈ø≈øens its e≈øteem, and may be termed the Wall, and Bulwark of Kingdoms the ≈øafe-Guard of private Per≈øons and the Handy craft Trad≈ø-man's only unum nece≈ø≈øarium, for without it few Imployments can ≈øub≈øi≈øt. As for its extraordinary hardne≈øs from over much Earthy parts, or fixed Sulphur in its compo≈øition; not, but it has a proportion of Quick ≈øilver in it, ≈øo that it will not without a very violent heat be melted, nor will it break, but expand by force of hammers, or other Violence, and receive an impre≈ø≈øion by dilating it ≈øelf; and although it is cold and dry, yet by rea≈øon it is more porous than other Metals, it is of le≈øs weight; and con≈øequently ≈øubject to be con≈øumed by ru≈øt.

Lead is frequently found in the Silver Mines, and indeed as often by it ≈øelf, nor ≈øcarcely is there any ore, but ≈øome quantity of Lead is found in its mixture, as being by the abundance of its humidity ≈øerviceable to it; and e≈øpecially in the melting of Gold, and Silver, which cannot conveniently be done without the help of Lead; for in this ca≈øe, by rea≈øon of its moi≈øture, it does ea≈øily evaporate, carrying with it whatever is not Gold, or Silver, and in its weight comes neare≈øt to the former, viz. Gold, and in Colour to Silver, not being ≈øubject to Corruption, as Iron.

Tin is begotten, or generated by a gro≈ø≈øer fore of indige≈øted Quick ≈øilver, though much finer than Lead, by which means, it becomes more
white, and hard, though from the ill mixture of its ≈øub≈øtance, it is accounted the Bane of Metals making them brittle by never ≈øo ≈ømall a mixture; and the rea≈øon is, that by its incorporation, it hinders the ductility, and di≈øorders its former equal temperature; except in Lead, with which it better agrees, by rea≈øon of the moi≈øture, and ≈øoftne≈øs; ≈øo that being incorporated they become ductil, and malleable.

Quick-≈øilver is of a liquid penetrating Sub≈øtance, and greatly in u≈øe; e≈øpecially in refining Metals, agreeing with any ≈øort, abounding with much humidity; which gives it brightne≈øs and weight, and is held the principal of the Generation of all Metals; nay its very ≈øub≈øtance is tran≈ømutable into Metals, enduring as well, as tho≈øe that come out of the Mines, the trial of the Fire, and Hammer.

There are ≈øundry Metals, called Artificial Metals, made by mixture of Minerals. As from a mixture of Tin, and Copper, Bra≈øs, or Bell-metal is made; as al≈øo for pieces of Ordnance, and ≈øundry other u≈øes: and in this ca≈øe, a pound of Tin mu≈øt be put from four, to eight pound of Copper, according as you expect it brittler, or tougher.

Latten is made of Plates of Copper, put into Cru≈øibles, and covered with Powder of J ‚Ä¢ lamina, or a kind of half Mineral Sulphur ≈øtrewed over it, and upon that, the Powder of beaten Gla≈øs, to which, Fire being put, and the ≈øteem, or greate≈øt force of it kept in, it alters

Pewter, a mixture of Lead, and Tin, and has ≈øometimes in it, for the better hardning, and keeping it together, a ≈ømall quantity of Bra≈øs, or Copper: And thus much for the Generation, and De≈øcription of Metals, which the Earth ≈øo abundantly produces for the u≈øe, and benefit of Man kind, from whence I proceed to the hardning of Metals, for Handy-craft, and ≈øundry other u≈øes.

And the fourth of Silver, and Copper only; the fir≈øt for the trial of Gold; and the latter for the trial of Silver, making of the≈øe mixtures twenty four Needles of ≈øundry finene≈ø≈øes. The third twenty two Carots of Gold, and two of Silver; and ≈øo proceed to one Carot wor≈øe, till there remains but one Carot of the fine Gold in mixture with the other Metals ≈øpecified, &c. viz. twenty three Carots of Silver, and by the ≈øame rule proceed to the Gold and Copper, and Silver and Copper, marking each Needle for the better di≈øtinction upon occa≈øion of what finene≈øs it is; and by this way, you may be ≈øatisfied of the finene≈øs of any Ingot, or piece of Gold or Silver in Coin or otherways by comparing them on your Touch-≈øtone with the Needle, who≈øe allay you already know, or trying them, till they become equal or alike, which when wetted will plainly appear. As for the value of Silver, that which is fine is accounted five ≈øhillings two pence of our Money the ounce, though there is ≈øome that will fall out in finene≈øs, to be worth five and eight pence, and the like. But the≈øe E≈ø≈øays not being to be done by every Per≈øon who receives Money, I ≈øhall by other ways in≈øtruct them how they may detect counterfeit Coins.

Pa≈øt doubt, few that have the handling of Money are ignorant, that Coins of all ≈øorts have been counterfeit, ≈øome by imba≈øing in mixture, others by corrupt Metals, and other by way of plating; and to know the≈øe; in ca≈øe of Guinneas or broad Gold, Fir≈øt, weigh them, and try them by E≈ø≈øay as afore≈øaid; and then if you further ≈øu≈øpect them, try them by Fire, or by Aqua fortis; and if they be of ba≈øe Metal, or corrupted with is, they will ≈øoon grow dim, and their Lu≈øtre in a ≈ømall time more and more impair; but if you ≈øu≈øpect them plated, e≈øpecially Guinneas, throw them indifferent hard on the edge, and the Imbo≈øsment will open, and you may di≈øcover the ≈øhell to ri≈øe. In ca≈øe of gilded Shillings, though they have the Scepters as Guinneas, which ≈øome Per≈øons have had the Art to place there with graving Tools; yet your be≈øt way is to try them by racing with a Pen-knife point in any convenient Place; and although they are double gilded, the Silver will appear.

The counterfeit Milled is wa≈øhed over or plated; and to di≈øcover this, you will find the Letters imperfect, or perhaps none upon the edges of Crowns or half Crowns; the ≈øound likewi≈øe will be flat and dull, and the Metal on the out≈øide may be ea≈øily rai≈øed to di≈øcover the defect.

As for old moneys, the wor≈øt ≈øize is the half Crowns with pieces of Copper plated over; and the≈øe you may know by their ri≈øing in the middle falling hollow, Mackle in the ≈øtamp, or better by
rai≈øing the thin Plate on the edge, and as for ≈ømaller money mo≈øtly mixed with Silver, your touch ≈øtone is the be≈øt tryer.

div.head: CHAP. IV. In≈øtructions for making black, red, white, green Inks, &c. for ≈øundry u≈øes as well ≈øolid as liquid, with that of the late Invention in Powder; Directions for my≈øterious writing, and other things, &c.
To make the be≈øt common or black Ink.
div.p: TAke a Gallon of Rain-water or clear Spring or running water, and put twelve ounces of Nut galls brui≈øed, or broken into it, and of Gum-arabick and Copperas of each two ounces, ≈øuffer it with once a day ≈øtirring to ≈øtand for the ≈øpace of twelve days in a warm place; and ≈øo u≈øe it as you have occa≈øion: And in this manner you may make a greater or le≈ø≈øer quantity; but if you want Ink of this kind for pre≈øent occa≈øion, you may boil your Ingredients in Vinegar and Water; but the Ink will not prove as the former.

div.head: To make red Ink.
div.p: Take the Powder of Braziel an ounce, white Lead and Alum of each two drams, Gum arabick a dram, put the≈øe into a pint of Urine, and ≈øtopped clo≈øe in a bottle, and often ≈øhake them together, and the bu≈øine≈øs will be effected.

div.head: Another way for red Ink.
div.p: Take of Gum arabick half an ounce, Vermilion an ounce and a half, Lake a quarter of an ounce, and Vinegar indifferent ≈øtrong a quart, mix them well together over a gentle Fire, and then ≈øuffer them to ≈øtand a while, ≈øhaking the Ve≈ø≈øel when you come to u≈øe it.

div.head: To make white Ink to write on Black Paper or the like: As in ca≈øe of Con≈øolatory Letters to tho≈øe who≈øe Friends are decea≈øed.
div.p: Take an ounce of chalk, as much Quick-lime, and a quarter of an ounce of Egg-≈øhell with half an ounce of burnt I≈øing-gla≈øs, grind them well together, and put them into Gum water of any kind to a thickne≈øs of writing, and the Ink by Candle-light e≈øpecially will appear like Silver.

div.head: To make Ink for the conveniency of Carriage in Powder, &c.
div.p: Take Lamp-black half an ounce, the Powder of Galls an ounce, Vitriol or Copper, as half an ounce, Gum-arabick a quarter of an ounce, Ivory black a quarter of an ounce make them into balls with water, adding if they ≈øtick not well together more Gum; and when you have occa≈øion to u≈øe it, ≈øcrape a little into a ≈ømall quantity of Wine, Water and Vinegar, and ≈øtir it about, and it will be exceeding black Ink immediately; and ≈øo you may be always provided with it without fear of ≈øpilling, or want of it in places of travelling, where there is none to be had, and in≈øtead of Lamp-black, you may u≈øe burnt Cherry-≈øtones ground to Powder.

div.head: To make a red Ink to carry to any Place as the former.
div.p: Take the Powder of Braziel finely ground or heaten one ounce, mix with it the juice of Mulberries or Black berries, or for want of them, water, wherein a little Lake has been di≈ø≈øolved, add Gum-arabick half an ounce, to two ounces of the Powder, wet them to a thickne≈øs, and making them up in Balls, u≈øe them as the former.

div.head: To make green Ink.
div.p: Take the filing of Copper an ounce, Verditer half an ounce, G ‚Ä¢ m-arabick half an ounce, and Vinegar half a pint, put them together in a ≈øtove or warm Oven, and ≈øuffer them to ≈øtand three or four days; then ≈øtir them together, and u≈øe the liquid part.

div.head: To make Ink that will make an Impre≈ø≈øion, as that of Printers, &c.
div.p: Take of Lamp black an ounce, or for want of it Shooe-makers black, half an ounce of Vitriol, an ounce of fine ground Char-coal; to the≈øe add a quart of Line-≈øeed Oil, boil them up with ≈øtirring over a gentle Fire, till they become of a ≈øufficient thickne≈øs; then take out the ≈øub≈øtance, and move it upon a ≈øtone or on an Ink-block with your Muller, till it is very fine; and ≈øo it will take the Impre≈ø≈øion as of Letters, &c. in the nature of Prints or Pictures, &c.

div.head: Red Ink of the foregoing kind,
div.p: Is made with Vermilion and Line-≈øeed Oil well tempered upon a ≈øtone with a Muller.

div.head: To write Letters invi≈øible but by Fire.
div.p:
You mu≈øt take the Juice of Limon and Onion,
temper them well together, and let your Paper be very dry; then write what you think convenient, and ≈øend it to the Party you de≈øign, who knowing the My≈øtery before-hand ≈øhall no ≈øooner hold it to the Fire, but tho≈øe Letters which were blank before will fairly appear.

div.head: To make Letters appear by water.
div.p: Take welld ried Paper, and having di≈ø≈øolved a quantity of Alum in Gum-water, write thereon, and ≈øuffering the writing to dry, dip the whole Paper under water, and the Letters will appear ≈øo much whiter than the re≈øt, that they may be plainly di≈øtingui≈øhed and read.

div.head: To make Letters that cannot be ≈øeen or read, but by reading them through the Paper, &c.
div.p: Take white Lead finely ground with very weak Gum-water, and with it as thin as the temperature of Ink, write upon exceeding white Paper, not very thick; and by that means when it is dry, it cannot be di≈øcerned from the Paper, but by looking at a light placed on the other ≈øide of the Paper; and then the Letters will plainly appear by denying your Eyes to penetrate them, though the Paper be tran≈øparent.

div.head: CHAP. V. Directions for clean≈øing, colouring Gloves, and perfuming them; the way to ≈øcour Ribbands without much impairing the Colour; the Method of wa≈øhing, ≈øtarching, &c. Silks, as Lute-≈øtring, Lawns, Tiffanies, Sarcenets, &c. with other matters of Curio≈øity.
Foul Gloves to clean≈øe without wetting.
div.p: TAke your Gloves, and lay them upon a clean board, and make a mixture of Fullingearth and Powder of Alum very dry, and pa≈øs them over on every ≈øide with an indifferent ≈øtiff bru≈øh; then ≈øweep of that and ≈øprinkle them with dried bran and whiting a con≈øiderable time; and ≈øo du≈øt them well, the which if they be not extraordinary grea≈øie, will render them clean as at fir≈øt; but if they be grea≈øy, you mu≈øt take out the grea≈øe with crumbs of toa≈øted bread, and powder of burnt bone; then pa≈øs them over with a woollen cloth dipp'd in Fulling earth or Alumpowder; and ≈øo you may clean≈øe them without wetting, which many times ≈øhrinks and ≈øpoils them.

div.head: To colour Gloves.
div.p: Take your Colours ≈øuitable to your intention, if dark take Spani≈øh brown and black Earth, if lighter, yellow Oker and whiting; and ≈øo of the re≈øt; mix them with a moderate ≈øize, and daub the Gloves over with the Colour wet, and ≈øo ≈øuffer them to hang, till they dry by degrees; then beat out the ≈øuperfluity of the Colour, and ≈ømooth them over with a ≈øtretching or ≈øleeking ≈øtick, reducing them to their proper ≈øhape.

div.head: To make an excellent Perfume for Gloves.
div.p: Take Amber-grea≈øe a dram, Civet the like quantity, Orange flower-Butter a quarter of an ounce; and with the≈øe well mixed and ordered, daub them over gently with fine Cotton-wool, and ≈øo pre≈øs the Perfume into them.

div.head: Another good Per≈øume on the like Occa≈øion.
div.p: Take of Damask or Ro≈øe-≈øcent half an ounce, the Spirit of Cloves and Mace of each a dram, Frankincen≈øe a quarter of an ounce, mix them together, and lay them in Papers between your Gloves, and being hard pre≈ø≈øed, the Gloves will take the ≈øcent in twenty four hours, and hardly lo≈øe it afterward.

div.head: To clean≈øe ca≈øt Bibbands, &c.
div.p: Take your Ribbands and ≈ømooth them out, having ≈øprinkled them a little before with fair water; then lay them on a Carpet or clean Cloth at full breadth, and having made a thin Ladder of Ca≈øteel ≈øoap, go over them gently with a bru≈øh or fine woollen Cloth; then having in readine≈øs water, wherein a little Alum, and white Tartar has been di≈ø≈øolved, go over them, till you ≈øee them clean; and ≈øo they will not only be clean, but the Colour will be fixed from further fading, if you ≈øuffer them to dry in the ≈øhade, and then ≈ømooth them out with a Gla≈øs Sleek≈øtone.

div.head: To wa≈øh black and white Sarcenet the be≈øt and ≈øure≈øt way.
div.p:
Lay the≈øe ≈ømooth and even upon a Board, or Carpet, ≈øpreading a little Soap over the dirty places; make a Ladder then with Ca≈øteel Soap, and having an indifferent fine bru≈øh, dip it therein, and pa≈øs over the Silks the right way, viz. longways, and repeat your ≈øo doing, till you perceive that ≈øide is ≈øufficiently ≈øcowred; and then turn the other, and u≈øe it in the ≈øame manner; whereupon take it up, and put it into fair water ≈øcalding hot, ≈øuffering them to lie, till ≈øuch time as you have prepared cold water, wherein a ≈ømall quantity of Gum-arabick has been di≈ø≈øolved,
as al≈øo, if for white Sarcinet, Smalt, into which you mu≈øt put them and rin≈øe them well, that done, take them out and fold them, clapping or pre≈ø≈øing out the water with your hands on a Carpet that is dry, keeping them under your hands in the like manner, till you find them indifferent dry; at what time in ca≈øe of the white, you mu≈øt have Brim≈øtone ready to ≈ømoak or dry it over, till it is ready for ≈ømoothing, which mu≈øt be done on the right ≈øide with a moderate hot Iron.

div.head: To wa≈øh and starch Ti≈ø≈øanies, &c.
div.p:
In this ca≈øe, the hems of your Tiffanies mu≈øt in the fir≈øt undertaking be only ≈øoaped a little; as al≈øo the Lace if any be on them; then having a Ladder of Soap, put them into it hot, and gently move them with ≈øqueezing them only, and not too roughly rubbing them, le≈øt they break or crumple over much; and when you find they are pretty clean, rin≈øe them in warm water, in which a little Gum arabick has been di≈ø≈øolved, keeping them as much from the Air as po≈ø≈øible; this done, make Starch of a rea≈øonable thickne≈øs, blewing it as you think convenient, adding a little lump of Alum to be di≈ø≈øolved therein; and when it is boiled to a convenient thickne≈øs, ≈øtrain it, and during its being hot, wet your Tiffanies therewith gently, doing it with a ≈øoft Linen rag, and fold them up in a clean Linen cloth, pre≈ø≈øing them therein, till they are ≈øomewhat dry, after
which, clap them between your hands near a good fire; and ≈øo fini≈øh the drying them over Brim≈øtone, and ≈øhape them to your purpo≈øe, and either ≈øleek them over, or gently Iron them.

Lawns may in the manner of the former be ordered. Only ob≈øerve to Iron them on the wrong ≈øide, and u≈øing Gum arabick water in≈øtead of Starch; and according to what has been directed for black Sarcenet any coloured Silks may be ordered abating, or augmenting as you think fit, according to the ≈øtiffne≈øs or limberne≈øs intended, your Gum-water.

div.head: To wa≈øh and ≈øtarch Point-Lace.
div.p: Have a Tent prepared, fix the Lace in it, and draw it pretty ≈øtreight; then having a Ladder of Ca≈øteel ≈øoap pretty warm, and with a fine bru≈øh dipped therein, rub over your point gently; and when you perceive it clean on the one ≈øide, do the like on the other; then ca≈øt fair water, in which a little Alum has been di≈ø≈øolved to take off the Suds; at what time having very thin Starch, go over with the ≈øame on the wrong ≈øide, and on the ≈øame ≈øide Iron it when dry; and ≈øo with a Bodkin open it, and ≈øet it in order.
To clean Point Lace, if not over dirty without wa≈øhing, ≈øix it in a Tent as the former, and go over with fine Bread, the Cru≈øt being pared off, and when it is done, du≈øt out the Crumbs, &c.

div.head: CHAP. VI. In≈øtructions for ordering and framing curious Wax-work, Imbo≈ø≈øing in Silver, or other Metals, making Flowers of Silk, carving and ca≈øting Imagery in ≈øundry Figures, the Art of poli≈øhing, &c.
Wax work its Nature, and how to be managed and performed.
div.p:
IN this ca≈øe you mu≈øt provide your ≈øelf with the fine≈øt Virgin Wax, rare≈øie it by often melting over a fire, till it become exceeding pliable, and render it the better, ≈øo put in a quantity of clarified Turpentine; and having con≈øidered your Figure, you mu≈øt work it in water a little Warm, and move it into a curious flatne≈øs, then imbo≈øs it in Moulds, or as ≈øome will have you, ca≈øt it, e≈øpecially where a curious re≈øemblance of a Head or Face is required, working the re≈øt of the Body proportionably upon ≈øticks or wiers, ruffling as you ≈øee convenient the Garments, or pleating them; then having your ≈øuitable Colours, paint each part as the property with Water Colours prepared according to what has been directed in painting or limning with tho≈øe Colours, and with a ≈ømall Ivory Poli≈øher go gently over tho≈øe parts you would have to ≈øhine; and
then having prepared Gla≈ø≈øes to cover them, which will give them the greater Lu≈øter, place them where you plea≈øe for Ornament.

As for Birds, Bea≈øts, Trees, Fruits and the like, they mu≈øt be tempered after their former manner, and reduced in their ≈øundry ≈øhapes, not forgetting every one to have its proper and natural Colour; and for the adornment of any Landskip, repre≈øent of this kind the Ground, where Gra≈øs is required may be Mo≈øs, which may in like manner ≈øerve for ≈øhrubs: But in ca≈øe of the Leaves of green Trees, they may be Paper or Horn, thin and finely coloured, ≈øhaped and wi≈øted upon wiers; in order as you ≈øhall ≈øee convenient: But as to every particular of this kind, 'tis only practice can perfect you.

div.head: To imbo≈øs Plate as Powter, Silver, or other Metal.
div.p:
Having your device drawn upon the piece you intend to imbo≈øs, you mu≈øt lay the right ≈øide upon a Bed of Bees-wax covered over with a fine Cloth; and ≈øo proceed to punch out the Metal with punchers or tools for that purpo≈øe, going over every ≈øtroak and Line as in ca≈øe of etching or graving, which done, you mu≈øt turn the right ≈øide, and fill the imbe≈øsments with war, that the hollows may bed clo≈øe and not ≈øink, then with your fine Tools and Graver poli≈øh and work the ≈øhapes in their due order by correcting and amending the roughne≈øs made by the punching out,
and giving fine touches and ≈øtroaks where you ≈øee it needful, and the Figures will appear very plea≈øant, being a Performance of great Antiquity.

div.head: To work Flowers, &c. in Silk or Silver.
div.p: Take raw or flea≈øy Silk of ≈øundry Colours comb out the dro≈øs or ravel, laying each Colour, by it ≈øelf; then twi≈øt and mingle the Colours by placing upon wires, according to the natural form of the flower intended, then comb them out, and fa≈øhion them more exactly with your ≈øci≈ø≈øors and Needle; then dip them in Gum-water; and by drawing them through it, and whil≈øt wet, open and ≈øhape them with your Fingers; that done, ≈øet them to drying in the ≈øhade; and in that form they will remain very plea≈øant and delightful: And thus you may perform them ≈øingle, or on Branches with the ≈øtalks ≈øuitable, &c. You may in this manner form Fruits and other things very material.

div.head: Carving of Images, &c. what is to be materi ‚Ä¢ lly ob≈øerved therein.
div.p:
Re≈øolving to carve any ‚Ä¢ urious Rigure you mu≈øt provide your ≈øelf with a ≈øi ‚Ä¢ ilitude or likene≈øs‚ñ™ either in Statue, or Porctraiture; whether it be for Wood, Ivory, or any thing tractable in this nature; and before you proceed to your rough carving with a black or red Lead Pencil, or piece
of Coal draw as well as may be the true Proportion, Po≈øture and Features, having before reduced the Wood or Stone to ≈øome ≈øet form; then cut them out as you ≈øee it convenient, or let them ≈øwell as curiou≈øly as may; then with ≈ømaller Tools proceed to poli≈øh them yet finer; and ≈øo working by degrees, till you have brought your matter to a proportion; and then remains the Curio≈øity of fa≈øhioning to the Life, and in this you mu≈øt be curious in eying your Copy, beginning with the head or upper part; and ≈øo de≈øcend by degrees, running it over three or four times before you come, either to wa≈øhing or poli≈øhing, that no un≈øeemly knob or other deformity may appear, &c. And in ca≈øe any Statue or Image, either ca≈øt or carved require to be painted in lively Colours, the rule for painting in Oil ought as well in the mixtures as laying on, to be ob≈øerved.

In ca≈øting of Images or Figures, the curio≈øity lies in forming the Mould, and bringing the ≈øtuff to a finene≈øs, which if done in beaten Chalk, Terrace, Plai≈øter of Paris or the like, they mu≈øt be mixed with Gum-water, the better to ≈øtrengthen them, but in ca≈øe of Lime, &c. it needs not; and then no more is required than bringing the ≈øtuff to a fit temper or ≈øtiffne≈øs of dough; and the Mould being to cla≈øp in the middle, and take a≈øunder, fill it with the Material, and ≈øqueeze it hard in a Vice, having rubbed the out-≈øide of the Mould before with dry whiting or chalk finely beaten, to prevent the ≈øticking, then take it out,
and ≈øet it to dry in a place where there is a ≈øtove; and when it is thoroughly dry, you may glaze or colour it at Plea≈øure.

If you de≈øign any Figure in Metal, and will not be at the trouble of imbo≈ø≈øing it in the expan≈øe; and ≈øo ≈øoldering it together, thereby rendering it hollow as in fine Metals 'tis often done; then mu≈øt you make your Mould of Brick, Chalk, fine Clay, or the like, and place it, when dry and firm in a Bed of Sand, or in the Ground, keeping it clo≈øe together; have then your Metal rarefied or purged from dro≈øs by well refining, and a trough or ≈øpout layed from the Plug of your Melter, and when the Metal is melted and skimmed, ≈øuffer it all at once to run with what ≈øpeed it may into the Mould, that every part taking hold of each other whil≈øt liquid, the whole Ma≈øs may the better incorporate and render the thing de≈øigned without flaw or ≈øcaling; ≈øuffer it then to be thoroughly cold before you take it out, which done, poli≈øh it by taking off the rough out≈øide, and proceed with your tools to rectifie what is un≈øeemly.

div.head: To poli≈øh Marble or any curious Stone.
div.p: Take fine Sand, and the Powder of Alaba≈øter, poli≈øh it with a Poli≈øher; and then ≈øuffer it to be laid over for a time with Oil; after that calcine, or burn Egg-≈øhells, and with the calcination thereof, rub off the Oil and poli≈øh it, and it will be of a la≈øting glo≈øs, &c.

div.head: To make any Writing on Parchment or from Paper, decay and become unlegible in a ≈øhort time.
div.p: Take Quick-lime, and mix with it the white of an Egg, and rub over with the ≈øaid mixture the Parchment or Paper, when you intend to write; and although the writing for a time will ≈øeem fair, it will in a ≈øhort time decay, and look ≈øo faint, that it can by no means be read.

div.head: To make new writing look old, and of a long ≈øtanding.
div.p: Take a dram of Saffron, and infu≈øe it into half a pint of Ink, and ≈øuffer it to warm over a gentle fire, and it will cau≈øe whatever is written with it to turn yellowi≈øh and appear as if of many years ≈øtanding.

div.head: To make a curious Purple Ink.
div.p: Take a quarter of an ounce of Lake and half an ounce of Indico, and brui≈øe them ≈ømall; which done, warm half a pint of water, and infu≈øe into it an ounce of Gum-arabick; then put the Colour in, and ≈øhake them well together.

div.head: Take Blots, or Letters out of Paper or Parchment.
div.p: Take an ounce of Alum, di≈ø≈øolve it in a quarter of a pint of water over a gentle Fire, and drop a drop of it warm as you ≈øee occa≈øion upon the ≈øpot, and ≈øuffering it to lie for a time, take it up again with clean Cotton Wool on which you have breached to moi≈øten it, and the bu≈øine≈øs in once or twice doing will be effected.

div.head: To render Writing very fair.
div.p: Take Gum ≈øandrick, brui≈øe and ≈øift it very fine, dip into it Cotton-Wool, and gently rub therewith your Paper or Parchment, and this is called the pouncing it, and is often u≈øed by School Ma≈øters to ≈øet of their Copies to advantage.

div.head: To write Letters like Gold without the help of Gold.
div.p: Take of Vermilion half an ounce, Gum-armoniack the like quantity, brui≈øe and mix then with the whites of a couple of Eggs, and temper them in water to a thinne≈øs, that you may write therewith; and then your writing being dry, glaze it over with a Poli≈øher.

div.head: To write Letters that will appear like Silver, without any Silver.
div.p: Take of Block-tin, Quick-≈øilver, and the whites of Eggs, each an ounce, melt the two former, and having ground them fine and ≈ømall, put them to the latter, and mix them with Gamwater to the thinne≈øs of Ink; and ≈øo proceed to write, poli≈øhing your writing, when dry.

div.head: How to prepare your Shell-Gold, and write with it.
div.p: Take the ragged cuttings of Leaf Gold, grind them upon a curious ≈ømooth and clean ≈øtone with Gum-water, and a little Alum Powder; and when they are well incorporated, drop of the ≈øub≈øtance into ≈ømall ≈øhells; and when you u≈øe it, temper a little fair water to bring it to a thinne≈øs; and having written with it your Plea≈øure, ≈øuffer it to dry, and then poli≈øh the writing, &c.

div.head: To make a good red ≈øealing wax.
div.p:
Take of Bees-wax a pound, fine Turpentine three ounces, red Lead, or Vermilion finely ground an ounce and a half, Olive Oil an ounce, melt well the Wax and Turpentine, adding an ounce of Ro≈øin fine in Powder; and when they ‚Ä¢ re well melted, and the dro≈øs taken off, put in ‚Ä¢ he Lead or Vermilion, and ≈øtir them well together

div.head: To make a Sun-dyal upon the Ceeling of a Room, and convey the beams of the Sun to it.
